Thats not the right way to think about it, youre sort of putting the cart before the horse. What determines the aggregate of wealth is the inefficiencies in the market. eg if I were the only person who knew that the true odds of a coin flip were 5050, I would buy up all the bets undervalued 49 and under until all that were left were 5050 bets. So yes, by the end of that process it is the aggregate of wealth that determines the prices, what determines the aggregate of wealth is the inefficiencies in the market before it. A market that rewards accuracy tends to be very accurate, even if 99 of the bettors in the market are clueless

Yes theyre called suckers and they lose all their money to sensible bettors and create an incentive for them to join the market in the first place. More suckers in a market will actually make it more efficient as the incentive to be accurate is now larger. Likewise, more attempts at manipulation Ive seen a lot of absolute nonsense going around at the moment that people are eating up actually incentivises the accuracy further. It might seem counterintuitive but its how it works

If you know for a fact its loaded its then not a gamble to say its loaded. You dont have to be a gambler you just have to have an incentive to make money. Or let the information get in the hands of someone who does. If someone knows, the market usually knows. Yes there might be rare cases where the one person who knows all 11 secret herbs and spices doesnt tell anyone else and doesnt like making loads of money for themselves, but as that information is not out there in any tangible form its stuck in someones head who doesnt join the market, no other predictive model could also know that information and betting markets would still be the most accurate predictive system out there. We can only compare them to other current predictive models polling etc and in that sense they win resoundingly and the evidence is there to back that up, even if you dont fully understand the mechanism behind it.

I get it, Tortoise vs Hare. The reason you want to park money into staples is precisely that they have a high likelihood of being around in 40, 60, 80 and 100 years and they are very likely to keep growing the entire time. This is why staples are powerful. For instance, pull up a sector market share chart. If you do that you will notice something interesting. Techs market share has actually gone no where since the late 60s. It peaked in the .com bubble and is again in a slight bubble now, but overall, not changed since then. What has changed is the companies within. Lots of boom and busts and big time consolidation and concentration of value. Staples havent really changed much either in terms of market share but like I try to describe above, its very easy to pick winners from staples precisely because they are not boom and bust. At worst, they get bought out but they will never go obsolete. This low risk characteristic is extremely valuable because even a dummy can pick winner 90 of the time. You cant say that about picking tech or finance or even energy stocks. Are the big tech giants of the 60s still around? Some yes, but mostly no. Are all those popular fracking companies from the 2000s still around? Most went under in the financial crash. And banks are like revolving bankruptcies even if they dont go under entirely.... Folks need to start respecting risk and practice risk mitigation. There is a total disregard for that on this channel in favor of getting rich quick on the next double or 10 bagger. Every portfolio posted is like 90 tech... many are 100 tech... its like everything thinks they will time the market just right to get out at peaks. It wont work. A few people will get rich, but most will look back and wish they bought KO instead.
COKE is a better investment than KO but it flies under the radar.

Some people may luck out in deflation. For example, if someone owned 50 of their investments in bonds and tbills, the price of the bonds would go up as rates are lowered to zero percent again. During deflation when nobody wants to spend money or borrow at 3 to buy a home, the bond holders could sell some highpriced bonds to the QE banks when bond prices are high and rates are low, and buy houses at bargain prices during times of super low mortgage rates. This is why its good to keep a few bonds in your investments because the next recession or depression cycle could unexpectedly appear at any time. Good quality long term maturity bonds help hedge recession and low rates. Tbills help hedge high rates set by the Fed.

Tell me you dont know anything about economics without telling me you dont know anything about economics. Deflation is bad for the economy because it discourages spending, investment, and consumption at the macro level. Sure, deflation would benefit inelastic essentials like food, but in a service based economy that relies heavily on capital investment and consumption, 8 deflation over several years would have disastrous effects. Deflation increases the purchasing power per dollar, which on the surface sounds good until you realize it also means wages will go down. It also discourages investment at all levels since rampant deflation would create a sentiment that its better to hold off since you can get more for your money later on. Why take the risk investing in the market or investing in RD if you could earn 8 just having the money sit in a bank account. High deflation would also decimate people with mortgages or loans since the payments on the loan remain the same while the purchasing power per dollar and their wages would be going down. So their monthly mortgage payments would be going up over time in real terms. High inflation is also bad, but a small amount of inflation like 2 benefits everyone because it means spending and investment is encouraged since money is losing 2 of its value if its doing nothing, and payments on mortgages and loans go down in real terms over long periods. Overall, deflation or zero inflation creates a culture of saving like in Japan and a small amount of inflation creates a culture of spendinginvesting.

Literally 100 of economists from across the ideological spectrum would tell you an 8 deflation rate would be disastrous. Everyone and every business would hold onto their money because its value would grow just by doing nothing. Investments would stall, consumer spending would drop precipitously beyond bare necessities, hiring would freeze, wages would fall, jobs would increasingly be lost, and economic growth would reverse. Respectfully, you have no idea what youre talking about.

replies.text: Kind of disagree. The consumer is sick of the Starbucks ripoff. Theyre looking for value, not sweet drinks that cost as much as a meal. Id been skeptical that just tweaks could fix that. I do believe making some big and fundamental and newsgenerating changes could fix Starbucks business. I also believe the small tweaks wont do anything. Seeing that 4 point letter from Niccol screams tweaks not true fundamental change. Its as much BS corpospeak as what Laxman was putting out. Empower the barista. Please. Ive read the employeedominated sub, and the theme is theyre sick of being worked to death and it sounds like many dont even like the customers. Understand the market isnt exactly a forensic fix for China. Customers tired of being ripped off dont need to be told the Starbucks story. The name on cups gag is played out. Making Starbucks a community coffeehouse isnt really what consumers want, and isnt necessarily good for the business. They want better value and they want to get in and out quickly. The 25 pop was the market assuming Niccol could make the inandout quickly thing, and the perceived value thing happen. This letter sounds like he doesnt even understand the problem. And the market annointing him as universal problem solving saint may be misguided. Yes, CMG stock had incredible growth and the brand became widely loved... for the first half of his tenure. But the second half is not as pretty. When problems started to appear, he seemed incapable of identifying and addressing them proactively. Chipotle is now widely perceived as being a ripoff and too bland. Bad portion sizes. Skimping on ingredients and quality. He seemed paralyzed and clueless about that. His last big public appearance before abandoning the ship was him goofily claiming the portions were consistent, as big as your head, and that if you ever felt you werent getting value, you should personally try to shame the worker into topping up your plate. Thats out of touch, not problem solving. So a perhaps more sober assessment of Niccol is that he was present while CMG rode the advantage of the stock being pummeled from killing customers with unsafe food, and then when the time came to actually solve problems, he couldnt recognize them let alone solve them. And now hes the one walking into a problemfest at Starbucks. I took my 24 gains and am waiting to see what happens. If I were given that job, instead of issuing that bad, pithy letter, heres what Id do acknowledge the deep problems which are a consumer no longer willing to pay luxury price for sugary milkshakes, employees placed in unfulfilling situations, operational inability to have quick, high volume output. fixes would be in the form of Big Bang changes and candid humility. Look to the dominos model where they apologized and acknowledged cardboard level pizza. Fix the bad, burnt coffee taste perception. look also to McDonalds who knows you have to keep volume going even when consumers are strapped and sick of you, and they do that with inarguably value through literal value menus. Id have some newsgenerating low priced options as a form of Starbucks value menu look also to McDonalds who figured out how to massively pump out drive through where your order is prepared in the time it takes between ordering and paying and pickup window, and then making that parallel with two or more lanes. Id overhaul the operations substantially. Despite what coffeehouse baristas think, efficient machines can make most of a drink just fine. Weve all had delicious mass produced smoothies, Nespressos, etc. Id lean heavy on such automation and preparation to massively ramp up how much and how quickly a location can pump out the drinks, and let the baristas be more of a presentation element. Let them use their time and personalities with the customers instead of tamping away and washing seives in the back. Yes, Id be fine with a scenario where premade or machine made drinks are pumped out under a counter and a charming baritas focus on pretending they made it and making the customer feel happy and that theyve been served quickly. Make it globally known that the long lineups are over and that you can get a plain coffee for 3 from the value menu. this would address both the biggest consumer deterrents plus make life liveable for the baristas. it turns Starbucks back into a perceived affordable treat, an attainable piece of luxury at a good price. Theres more, but you get the point. Sure, theres a halo on Niccol, and a whole ecosystem of Wall Street and financial news media that is invested in claiming Starbucks is great regardless of the truth. But in terms of actual transformational change, my plan seems to have more substance than tell the Starbucks story

Ill go back to Starbucks if they drop prices by 50 and put tables back in their shops. I havent been in years because its overpriced and not even good coffee. Plus no one meets at Starbucks anymore. Its that simple.

I do this as a hobby, I like analyzing public companies. I find writing a good way to organize my analysis. The level of knowledge in this subreddit varies, so one of the goals of my posts is to make it understandable for everyone. Also, I am a fan of the quote If you cant explain it simply, you dont understand it well enough. I can use complex terms as I have the knowledge, but Ill argue that will add less value overall. Id appreciate your feedback if you read the entire post, and let me know if you disagree with it.

Mortgage companies dont believe that the Fed Reserve rate is going to remain low.
The article We expect mortgages around 6 for the next 12 months You Fed must be reversing course

Mortgage rates really have nothing much to do with the cash rate anyway, the 10Y bond is far more influential. And it makes perfect sense that cutting the cash rate in a decent economy so that the boom times would continue would result in higher long term growth expectations, and therefore a higher 10Y bond yield. Probably actually likely that the cash rate continues down to somewhere in the 3s and the 10Y goes back up to somewhere in the 4s and we return to a normal world of positive duration spread rather than the inversion weve had for 2 years.
Yes....

Mortgage rates really have nothing much to do with the cash rate anyway, the 10Y bond is far more influential. All the rates play off the Federal Reserve rate. Theyre essentially all correlated. If banks believe that the Fed Reserve rate is going to fall in the future you would expect the mortgage rates to fall with it. But, if the banks believe that the pullback is going to be temporary theyll keep them where theyre at.

In China, foreign competitors were denied access to their local market and all EV OEMs were coerced to switch to local suppliers to get permit and subsidies. Now even if we pretend thats what Italy did with Industria 4.0, the complianant must demonstrate that Italys subsidy caused injury to local industryinterest to pursue an action against Italy. So its fairly difficult to bring an antisubsidy case against another country. The EU fired the first warning shot against Chinas NEV regulation back in 2018 when it filed another WTO case WTDS549 still open, but had to wait another 5 years to bring the antisubsidy case against China as Chinese EVs flooded the EU market.

content.text: European Union votes to impose tariffs on Chinese electric vehicles

As the riskfree rate of return goes down, the benefit of taking the extra risk of investing in the SP 500 increases, so more people do so, causing it to go up in value until the difference between the SP 500s expected return and the riskfree rate of return is the same as it was before. As a result, the SP 500 can also go up as people suspect the riskfree rate of return will decrease. And if those expectations prove false, the SP 500 can go back down. The SP 500 is an index of the 500 largest companies in the USA weighted by market cap how big they are.

It is humans trying to derive a pattern out of chaos. Its like me looking at a chart of my heart rate for the past 12 months and guessing at what it will be next week at 12pm based on past data. Benjamin Graham Warren Buffets mentor had a good quote. In the short run, the market is a voting machine but in the long run, it is a weighing machine So long story short day to day fluctuations are meaningless, in the long term good businesses will grow and if you bought their stock AT THE RIGHT PRICE your wealth will grow along with them. Why do you think distribution is a strong moat? The shelf space gives them an advantage against other start ups but is still tied to their own performance and bigger brands can still just substitute old products with new ones and be an immediate treat due to the low entry barrier. 23 of the category sales is through retail, so ecommerce is also not that important for snacksbars I would be really cautious about your assumption of a health conscious consumer. While I would agree that healthier eating is on the raise it doesnt mean plant based alternatives are also winning. Actually we know from trails at McDonalds and the evolution of plant based brands like Oatly that the demand might be limited. Simply Good Food does seem to be managed well as they are decreasing debt while increasing margins but for a growth stock the falling revenue growth is still a warning sign. Which seems to be reflected in the current stock performance. In general, I dont see a point in creating a 20 year strategy with single stocks. What might be a good stock now can be seen completely different in the 510 years because of bad management, macroeconomics, regulatory changes or consumer behavior shifts. If you believe in the category its probably more of an ETF or managed funds opportunity.

Whenever Im looking at a single stock investment, I always ask myself if I think the company will beat the passive part of my portfolio. Do you think this will beat the benchmarks lets say SPY or QQQ over the next 135 years? If so, why?

Power Crunch are like sugar wafers so have an enjoyable crunch, crunch, crunch to them. Atkins Ive never tried, always too expensive. It seemed like they were marketing to keto people. If I were to research them for comparisons, I would look at the various sugar alcohols. replies.text: Actually enjoyed it! Thank you for putting in the work, love quality Posts in this sub. Football Clubs are a shitty value investment, therefore I didnt wanted to read through this and fast forwarded to the end. But i noticed you came to the exact same conclusion and worked your way through the fundamentals and many different aspects. Little Bit of wasted work for Man United but fundamentally good Analysis and solid quality post. We need more of this here.

This is generally right. Sports teams are possibly more like high end art as an investment than they are like a normal business. I cant speak for MANU specifically, but in the U.S. there are often ways that the owners benefit financially from owning a team that will not show up on the company books. For instance, they might own most of the parking near the stadium but privately or in a separate entity. In a publicly traded company like MANU that doesnt help shareholders any but it does mean that owning the team is more valuable to a buyer than simply being able to show off.

There is big fund that invests into football clubs like Manchester, Juventus and Celtic. Here is a article about it I dont think retail investors should invest in sports clubs. Their goal is to win titles and not to generate cash flow for shareholders. Any excessive cash is spent on new players or infrastructure. A club can also have bad financials and still be successful.

The market cap of every NFL team combined is less than companies like Home Depot, Roche Pharmaceuticals, Salesforce, Hermes, and Costco. They have an outsized cultural impact, but that doesnt mean they are financial powerhouses.

Lots of owners have made a lot of money in football. The key is not managing the club you buy like a squirrel regard. Hell, you are talking about Manchester United which was managed like a squirrels dropping, and it still made lots of money for the Glazers. They basically put nothing in, leveraging the clubs money and sold part of their stake for 4bil

I didnt read your entire post so take this for what it is, but I think the thing about football clubs is they generate a lot of hype from people because everyone in the world knows about them and they sell out stadiums easily and have sponsorships, but the reality is they also spend a ton of money on players and stadiums and a bunch of expenses so in reality its not a really great business, to me the only time Ive thought about buying football clubs stock is right during the IPO because thats when the hype for them really gets going as every fan wants a piece and big investors see it as initially undervalued, but yeah I think their value as actual businesses that continually have stock growth is dubious in general but during IPOs theyre at least worth a glance.

As Premier League fan for over 20years I have to say that Man United has a lot to catch up on compared to other top clubs assuming United can still be considered as top club they finished in top4 only 4 times in last 10 years, not winning the league even once. I read many interviews with former players complaining about the infrastructure, work ethics etc. The club is also far behind when it comes to use of technology and data. Imo Man United is still capitalizing on thier popularity that was build during their best years 19952013. It is definitely not the club that is going upwards both as a sport club and as a company. Also whoever came up with the idea to give it the ticket MANU clearly doesnt know club history. Google ,,why not to call Manchester United as Man U.
Nice Post, interesting to read.

So, you might ask What is the value of a company that is not profitable, operates in a competitive field, and even success is temporary? The answer will likely be 0. Uh....dude, you value them the way you normally do and, no, dont use GAAPbased Net Income.....saw you flagged a bunch of noncash expenses that can generally be ignored during a valuation exercise.... by looking at historic actual operating cash flow and EBITDA values consensus broker estimates on the next two years worth of cash flows 5.0 There is no value? So, is there no value? Is one of the biggest clubs in the world worthless? For a company the generates 100mm to 200mm in organic cash flow per year? Yeah, Id say theres a good bit of value in there. This fact is further backed up when looking at MANUs trading multiples which all are in a fairly reasonable range of 18.0x 13.0x on an Firm Value EBITDA basis and 17.0x 8.0x on a Market Cap OCF basis..... Id argue that Manchester United, like other sports clubs, arent valued, as theres no significant positive free cash flow. Instead, they are being priced. They are in the same group as Pokemon cards, antiques, and art paintings. The beauty is in the eye of the beholder. Except, the beholders are billionaires, and theyre likely going through a checklist. I think this line of logic is flawed since a weve shown that MANU does consistently generate cash flow no, cash flow accrual income and arent valued based on greaterfool or bag holder theory like noncash yielding investments like Pokemon cards, Beanie Babies, Crypto, etc.....

Valuable analysis, Sir. Manchester City take raw young players, improve them, and turn them into valuable stars that any other team would bite their arm off for. Precisely the opposite business model to Utd. The beautiful, freeflowing football of Utds oncehapless local rivals has undermined the clubs ability to set a course then stick to it. We shouldnt underestimate the demoralising effect of the greatest football team in modern history emerging in their own back yard. Its economically not insignificant.
Interestingly I just came to know that Ariel Investments, a value fund with a long history, are invested in Manchester United. Surprised me.
Glad you enjoyed it, and thank you for the kind words.
Tottaly agree!
TV money in sports is outrageous, and I dont see that changing anytime soon. FSG have made bank on Liverpool FC, so you can money off them if you dont buy it as a vanity project.
Their goal is to win titles and not to generate cash flow for shareholders Very much not true for United under the Glazers ownership! Hopefully the Ratcliffe era is different.
Good point.
I understand the post is long, and I do think if you read it, youd see some overlap between your line of thinking and mine
Thank you, glad you enjoyed it.
Using EBITDA is pointless when the club has to continuously buy new players. This is completely ignored by your approach, and it is quite a significant cash outflow.
They generate OCF, they dont generate FCF. Transfer fees are recurring and necessary. I dont think theres a point to a valuation method that excludes them.
Using generic valuation methods for a sports team shows you dont know anything

It should also be noted that a key part of Man Citys business model is taking fake and inflated commercial sponsorships from the UAE. Their state owner with a horrific human rights record. Thats the reason theyre currently facing 115 charges for financial misconduct, and could be stripped of their titles andor relegated if found guilty.

The length depends on the complexity. In this case, it was not more than 2 days.
Thats still some dedication
I really like analyzing companies and that helps a lot I am glad that the posts are welcomed in the subreddit and theres positive feedback.

replies.text: I would not buy Rivian unless I was trying to swing trade from something like 5 a share. I understand the product is good, but the cash burn is way too aggressive and the car industry is just very hard to succeed in. I would say the same thing about most other EV stocks. There are better opportunities for speculative investments in other sectors.
So everyone saying no ha??? So I guess Im in then

It was trading a 8.40 in April prior to the 1 billion dollar lifeline up to a total of 5 billion by VW for their joint venture. It is now trading at 11.17. This seems like a good entry point if you think the R2 will be a successful product. I picked up some shares the last few days but its still a gamble and you should treat it as such. There is no sensible reason to buy a Rivian with their low number of service centers, high repair costs, and high insurance costs... but damn, do they ever have a good looking product.
Until they get the Georgia plant going, Im staying away as far as possible. Output is too damn low for its valuation.

The way to profit from EV is not to buy Tesla or Rivian etc.. they have huge capital investments competition and have to take risks. The way to play is follow the classic picks and shovels strategy.. buy the supply chain players.. power semiconductors, lithium, copper, electrical connections, charging infrastructure, etc. electrification is a given... These companies will make money. Selling EV at loss that replaces ICE vehicles is not going to make you money as you are replacing one with another... Not necessarily increasing sales...

Just buy it. High risk but high reward. We all hold a few of these. Buy it and look at it after R12 and R13 numbers come out 2026. If its anything like the bump to profitability Tesla got look out. They are very busy selling everything they make. Look at the website store for what is available nationwide. I think they only have a few 3 or 4 R1S trimotors in the store. They are also busy building service centers and charging stations. As these numbers grow and people live closer to service centers the sales numbers will continue to grow. They have a unique product unlike anything on market now. They have also retooled the factory and make motors in house etc. so the cost per vehicle is going down to make. Lastly I own the stock and like it full disclosure.

Bought a small position earlier this year at 10.50 and sold after the Volkswagen news. Havent looked at it since then until now and saw its back around 11. Love the vehicle, company seems like headache though from everything Ive seenlooked at myself. What are they doing to fix their burn rate. The money from Volkswagen is nice but that doesnt solve their problem it just postpones it. Is there any evidence the cheaper Models will have higher margins? Thats their biggest issue. How do they fix it? Will fixing it make their product worse? Etc. Etc. Im happy to root from the sidelines and am rooting for the company but their seems like way easier ways to make money.

I live in a HCAOL and Im seeing more and more Rivians. They look great and I think they might be able to take some Tesla business. I bought a couple hundred shares on that possibility alone. We will see.

IMO, right now is too early. Even if they have a profitable grossmargin by Q4 with the R1 Gen2, theyll still bleed about 1Bquarter, based on their past financials. And thats going to be a long 56 quarters until the R2 starts production. And then you run the risk of R2 sales not meeting expectations.

They have a partnership with Amazon, there is currently more than 10,000 rivian trucks delivering for Amazon and more to come, they were partnered with Mercedes as well but rivian dropped that partnership themselves. Give this company 5 years and its gona dominate mark my words.

Management doesnt care about shareholders at all. Anyone objectively looking at the stock can see the ridiculously high cash burn rate, the shareholder dilution, and the ever increasing debt loads. Theyve missed virtually every metric they ever set and dont even have their performance compensation tied to company performance. Note that gross margin is still massively negative, meaning theyre selling their vehicles for less than the basic raw materials and labor to build the vehicles even cost something Tesla and other EV makers never did. Imo wait until they show a clear path to profitability before buying. This is a company that has the potential to thrive but in its current state the stock is just a piggy bank that the execs are using to increase their own wealth while they dilute and destroy shareholder value.

I think its possible in the next 510 years as self driving tech advance car ownership could change. Too much potential for major market dynamics shift. True self driving on open roads could make the concept of owning a car change. If you can pull it an app and have ANY car you want for however long you want and get rid of it immediately after really changes how people relate to cars and makes it possible for them to be much more expensive. Im not saying it will happen but its very much a possibility so Im staying away for now

Bought 100k worth at 13share. Its risky of course but the upside can be huge. My prediction is that there will be another bull run on EV and this will 10x. EV is way early and burning cash is normal when youre building manufacturing plants and cars from the ground up. They pass the eye test too...I see way more Rivians than anything other non Tesla EV

With Rivians stock dropping significantly since its IPO, People looking at the IPO price and how much its down since it should have never been at that price. They were lucky to go public at that valuation, but shareholders who piled into that bubble got obliterated. Looking forward, RIVN probably is one of the few smaller companies that went public in 202021 who will get through this period but I dont think thats ultimately as exciting as people think. Too many people still treating the EV theme like its the 202021 bubble and trying to pick the next Tesla. Meanwhile, a number of 202021 EV ipospac names are already 0s some of which are 0s for the second time. The automobile business with a couple of exceptions is not a great business I mean, again multiple EV companies that went public a few years ago already 0s and Tesla made everyone think it is, despite Musk frequently going on about what a difficult business it is over the years. So, can RIVN bounce? Sure. Is it going lower if there was a recession in the next couple years? Absolutely. Do I think it can be one of the few smaller names that ultimately gets through this period? Yes, but I think the market has gone back to the idea that automobiles are not a great business and people keep wanting them to be something they arent. So, I think RIVN could bounce on any good news, its going to be a tough hold through whenever the next recession is and on the other side of that will probably do fine on the upturn but I think people still expect too muchis it the next TSLA!?!?! from the theme.

I was a huge Tesla fan until Elon started behaving like Trump just a younger version and possibly a more deadlier version with his Space X and Twitter companies to influence the world. I have been marveling at the Rivian and am totally impress with the quality with the recent visit to their showroom.

I do not know much about Rivian.. but as an investor for you to make money they have to sell a lot more vehicles at profit while investing in massive factories and competing with other players Instead I would bet on lithium miners like albamerle or sqm and other lithium lifecycle companies beyond miners. I heard battery might be commoditized .. so maybe battery recycling. Think what changes in the car architecture.. more motors more copper more high voltage electric lines and interconnects .. companies like molex amphenol comes to mind. Then semiconductors that focus on power conversions and controls like nxp infineon renesas will also win irrespective of who sells more EV. Then there are utility companies which should see more demand along with data centers. There is massive work in EV infrastructure and charging but again focus on the vendors and not necessarily blink or charge point. Along with ev.. there will be a shift to automation .. the players making the cameras lidar chips and software would make more profit than waymo Tesla or gm who are competing to bring the vehicles. It doesnt mean that Rivian or Tesla is a bad investment but its no longer a first mover environment... I have no idea of knowing if they will or will not but if I trust that EV is going to be the future.. then I would bet on the supply chain. Solar might be a big winner in EV . Not so much in data center case. Think ancillary issues... Charging time is still a problem... Land is limited... You want chargers in strategic location. Who has land that might become useless with ev chargers.. think the gas stations... So they will transition there with scope of commercial real estate developing. Else the grid will transition to micro grid with battery storage becoming more critical.

Of course, you can always use the normal video player app to watch movies you downloaded to the device. The watching experience is great, especially on the Quest 3. Its just a shame there isnt more support from the developers when it comes to the Quest apps.

I dont wear glasses but I live with someone who does. She is able to use the Quest 3 with her glasses on and she says its pretty comfortable. You can also get prescription lenses that simply anap in over the built in lenses for like 50 on Zenni, which we havent received yet but I imagine will be just like playing without glassescontacts on at all but still have the clear vision.

Watching media in a VR headset is a really cool experience, but apps like Netflix either arent good or arent available in the headset, so you often have to use the browser for them. Thats another case where having a high powered PC makes the headset better because you can just mirror your computer screen. Theres exercise and productivity uses for it, but I dont have much experience with that. Some people love it, but both those cases work better if you can see your environment. Unfortunately the passthrough is just not quite there yet to make it usable for long periods of time for me personally. Thats why Meta is making glasses so you dont need passthrough. Even though theres benefits, its hard to convince people to do their entertainment, exercise, and productivity inside of VRAR when the drawbacks are so apparent. Again, I love my Quest 3 though and recommend it to people, but theres a ways to go before it will get widespread adoption. Itll get there, Meta is doing a great job imo in innovating in this space.

replies.text: Has gone largely nowhere since Fall of 2005 and Ive seen more than a couple of discussions about housingland value in the time since. Land inof itself isnt a positive see also TRC. Produce is a commodity and agribusiness like this is inconsistentvolatile. Water rights are a plus. If you have land and you dont have great management and there isnt some sort of end goal to monetize the whole thing, youre going to have a stock that looks like this or TRC is another, similar example. For all the Ackman presentations and various discount to NAV stories about Howard Hughes HHH over the years, its still way under where it was when there was the Baby Buffett Forbes cover story from 2015 about Ackman potentially turning it into his Berkshire. Real estaterelated companies like the above three that are real estate companies with a mix of assets and that arent REITs often have difficulty attracting an audience and for all the look at the land! they continually trade at some degree of a discount. I think Ive read dozens of HHH sum of the parts thesis reports over the years and yet, after all that, it wasnt bought by Brookfield or Blackstone, its Ackman who has been the one buying it up in the last year or so and maybe he eventually does turn it into his Berkshire, but if thats the case the purchase price will still probably be under where it was when that article was written. Nothing against it and hope you do well, but this has basically been volatile within a range for almost 20 years. IMO, that will most likely continue to be the case as a public company they need to look at a sale. As a public company, all of the assets will likely continue to trade at a discount detailed discussion of NAVdiscount here , so best case at this point is a compelling sale to someone else. As that link notes, being a public company the only reason why they became a public company in the first place was because they eventually had enough shareholders to require reporting hasnt really benefitted it much. The CEO who has been the CEO now for 20 years said pretty much the same last year when it was announced that they were looking at strategic alternatives The value the market perceives we have versus what we believe is the intrinsic value theres always been a big difference between those two things, said Harold Edwards, who has been Limoneiras CEO since 2004. The idea is that maybe theres a better way for us to operate. Maybe theres a better ownership structure that isnt public. Maybe its private, or maybe its merging together with another public company. TLDR As a public company, the next 10 years will probably resemble the last 10 years. Im not some crypto bro but this is a silly question. The answer for what it does better is literally everything. If Solana were the currency people used, for instance, I could send Solana right now, any amount, as many times as I want, to anyone I want, for fractions of a cent. And they would get it instantly. And it will be fully recorded and trackable forever. I work in real estate and dealing with fiat currency is a constant headache by comparison. To pay bills in the amounts and frequency I need I have to use my banks billpayACH system which costs 25 per transaction, takes 36 days to process, and only processes during banking hours. My only access to the history of those transactions if I need it is within whatever limitations my bank puts on their online reporting sometimes as little as 30 days depending on the bank. If my bank doesnt like where Im sending it to or how often Im doing it they can just decline to let the money be sent, at any time, because they feel like it. ZelleVenmo arent real things here, as they are just essentially loans from banks that cover the processing time of the actual transfers, and from a feasibility standpoint if youre moving around money frequently or in high amounts ZelleVenmo will shut you down real fast or put cooldown periods on your account where you cant use it for a few weeks. Were talking about a few thousand dollars here. And god forbid I need to transfer 6 figures or more not uncommon in real estate. Then Ive got to go into the bank, during banking hours, and show ID. All of this to access and move around my own money. None of which is a problem with crypto, where your own money is actually your own money and you can do what you want with your money instead of what a bank will let you do with your own money.

Its the ability to move substantial funds, crossborder, instantly for almost free. Or the ability to hold a form of wealth outside of a third party custodian if required. That is only bitcoin of course. Lots of other stuff out there. Look at stable coins for example. Around 100b deployed and heavily in use for crossborder payments. replies.text: Will the real estate locations increase in value? Probably. Will the debtfilled REITs that own the buildings survive? That is a different question.

Catching a falling knife is difficult. Many experts state that commercial real estate especially office buildings is one of the remaining bubbles to pop. Virtually every pre2022 commercial loan is underwater, and the banks have been loathe to write those investments down. My interpretation of that is that the worst is yet to come, and either the prices have already captured this prediction staying flat or have still underestimated the fallout dropping still furtherclosing down of REITs. Best of luck in your decision making!

While DEA might be a bargain, it is too early to tell where office REITs are going to go. The workplace was changed by COVID which in less than a year threw out all the assumptions that flexible work hours couldnt work. DEA rents to the guvment, so the crash it took with all the other REITs, was way overdone. But I would be wary about any other office type REITs until it is clear if the change in work life is indeed permanent or not.

All I can tell you is I have several friends in B2B banking that specialize in real estate development funding. They are currently on a freeze for any loans for office space development or refurbishment. Several of their active projects have been paused for over a year while they decide if they continue or try to pivot the build purpose. Im not saying well never have offices again, just that I think the industry still has a lot of pain coming and I wouldnt gamble on any office specific REITs

Holy ChatGPT If you expect a 25 bps cut and bonds are too expensive Short Bonds Since bonds are overvalued too expensive for a 25 bps rate cut, you could short bonds betting the price will fall. As the market realizes the smaller cut, bond prices could decrease, allowing you to profit from the short position. If you expect a 50 bps cut and bonds are too cheap Buy Bonds Go Long If youre certain that rates will be cut by 50 bps, and bonds are currently undervalued too cheap, bond prices are likely to rise after the announcement. You can go long on bonds, expecting a price increase. Using Leverage Leverage allows you to amplify returns. If youre confident in your prediction, you can use leverage to increase your exposure to the trade. However, keep in mind that leverage also increases the risk of losses if the trade goes against you. For example If you expect a 50 bps rate cut and bonds are undervalued, you could borrow money to buy more bonds than you could with your own capital. When bond prices increase, your returns will be multiplied based on the leverage used. Similarly, if you short bonds expecting a 25 bps cut and prices fall, leverage can increase your profits from the price decline. Risk Considerations Certainty Be cautious about being 100 sure of rate cuts, as central bank decisions can be unpredictable. Misjudging the rate cut could lead to significant losses, especially if using leverage. Market Reactions Sometimes, even when you predict the rate cut correctly, the market may have already priced it in, or there may be other factors influencing bond prices. Always consider these potential risks. By timing your trades based on rate cuts and leveraging your position, you can potentially generate large returns. However, proper risk management and a solid understanding of bond market dynamics are essential.

The bull case for NVIDIA, despite the potential cracks in the AI scaling hypothesis, remains compelling due to a number of factors 1. AI Beyond Scaling Diversification of Architectures While the scaling hypothesis may face limitations, NVIDIA is not solely reliant on larger models for growth. The shift towards diverse architecturessuch as edge computing, federated learning, and more efficient, adaptable modelsstill heavily depends on advanced hardware. NVIDIAs innovation in custom AI chips and specialized GPUs for varied workloads ensures that it continues to dominate, even as the industry pivots away from pure scale. 2. AI Software Ecosystem NVIDIAs CUDA platform, AI software stack, and Deep Learning SDKs offer essential tools for AI developers. These tools are deeply integrated across the AI research and enterprise ecosystems, which means that even if scaling slows, NVIDIAs software dominance secures its position as a key player. Moreover, AI companies are dependent on NVIDIAs endtoend platform, from training to deployment, and this dependency is unlikely to change even if the emphasis shifts from scale to smarter, more efficient architectures. 3. Enterprise and Data Center Expansion Even beyond researchdriven AI, enterprise adoption of AI is growing rapidly. Companies across industriesfinance, healthcare, and logisticsare integrating AI into their operations, and this trend fuels continued demand for highperformance computing HPC solutions. NVIDIAs foothold in data centers is a major asset, as demand for AIpowered insights and automation continues to grow. The company is positioned to benefit from AIdriven automation, which is expected to scale massively in the next few years. 4. AI in Autonomous Systems NVIDIAs leadership in autonomous vehicles, robotics, and other AIdriven automation solutions offers another strong growth avenue. The companys Drive platform for autonomous driving and its investments in industrial robots and AIpowered edge devices place NVIDIA in a favorable position as automation accelerates across multiple industries. 5. Gaming and Virtual Worlds Metaverse While AI remains the main growth driver, NVIDIAs core business in gaming is still robust, and its investment in the metaverseparticularly via its Omniverse platformis positioned for future growth. The convergence of AI, VR, and GPUpowered graphics in virtual worlds will open up new revenue streams, ensuring that NVIDIAs hardware remains in demand across various sectors beyond traditional AI use cases. 6. AI Custom Silicon and Competition NVIDIA is investing heavily in custom silicon AIspecific hardware. The Grace CPU and Grace Hopper Superchip, alongside nextgen H100 GPUs, cater to evolving needs in AI and HPC. These chips optimize AI workloads and enable costeffective scaling, keeping NVIDIA ahead of competitors like AMD and Intel. 7. AI as a Deflationary Force The massive potential of AI to create efficiencies across industries means that the macroeconomic environment will continue to favor companies like NVIDIA. As AI proves its worth in reducing operational costs, improving supply chains, and automating workflows, NVIDIAs role in supplying the necessary infrastructure will keep demand strong. Conclusion Bull Case for NVDA Despite possible challenges to the scalability hypothesis, NVIDIA remains a key enabler of the AI economy. Its leadership in hardware and software, expansion into new markets like autonomous vehicles, and diverse revenue streams provide a strong foundation for continued growth. Even if the AI bubble bursts in some areas, the underlying technological advancements and enterprise applications are likely to sustain NVIDIAs trajectory.

How to cheat the market of 20 trillion? Over two years 1H24 to 1H22, net income of US public nonfinancial companies declined by 1.5 at par and fell by 7.9 on an inflationadjusted basis. Meanwhile, moderate stagnation with a downward trajectory was driven by the strong performance of technology companies, i.e. excluding technology and trading Amazon factor, profits collapsed 18 at par and 23.3 when adjusted for inflation. At the same time, the US market was balancing in the 36003800 range with a break to 3500 points 1H22 reports were known, as they are now for 1H24. Profits were down by a quarter in real terms with no successful reps in tech, and this was presented as a 20 trillion dollar success the difference in capitalization now and then. Mental distortions, AI hallucinations, pure idiocy, baybucks and highly concentrated insanity are the ingredients of a 20 trillion success and nothing more. Someone dreamed that they started growing at the economic boom rate of the 90s, when in reality its stagnation with a downward slope on a high base. This is no longer in the field of economics, it is pure psychiatry and social engineering. The results in 2024 are worse than 2022, and the elation is as if one has teleported to an alternate universe of magical dreams, a fairy tale utopia AI world and incredible cash flows that dont exist. Is it true that technology is showing an increase in profits? Yes, its true. A historic high in absolutes and high growth rates, yet everyone else is in severe decline by their own calculations based on company reports Trading 10.7 yy and 43.5 for 2Q24, and for 1H24 11.6 yy and 44.2 for two years further in the sequence shown. Medical 38.9 and 22.2 19.5 and 44.9 ! Consumer Discretionary 23.6 and 2.1 due to Warner Bros. 10 bln loss 8.7 and 0.7. Industrials 4.4 and 4.7 9.3 and 10.3. Commodities and utilities 13 and 52.1 21.1 and 33.9 ! Transportation and communications 37.5 and 0.1 10 and 5.8. Technology 22.8 and 38.9 30.7 and 24. These data, please note, are at par! If we compare 1H24 to 1H22, three sectors are in the negative medical, raw materials and transportation, communications, two are in the zero consumer discretionary and industrials and only two sectors are in the plus technology and trade due to Amazon. There are literally 10 tech companies in good profit, everyone else is very bad. But everyone else is on the hai look it up.

So the time is up on the position and Person B needs to return the shares they borrowed. You have the only shares and wont sell them back to Person B so they can return them to you. This creates a failure to deliver, actually 2 as they were borrowed twice. So this could create infinite borrowed sharesFTDs. You have about T35 or whatever to settle a FTD. T35 happens and your FTDs are not closed but put into the obligations warehouse because the enforcer, says you are all good. Now the process starts again. I think the big problem occurs with borrowing the same thing twice. Somethings gotta give. The problem is the FTD. This is where the phantom sharesnaked shares are created. Crazy system we have here.

How to cheat the market of 20 trillion? Over two years 1H24 to 1H22, net income of US public nonfinancial companies declined by 1.5 at par and fell by 7.9 on an inflationadjusted basis. Meanwhile, moderate stagnation with a downward trajectory was driven by the strong performance of technology companies, i.e. excluding technology and trading Amazon factor, profits collapsed 18 at par and 23.3 when adjusted for inflation. The issue about unavailability of workers is largely bogus and typically written by unknowledgeable people. Sure, one needs to train technicians to work in the clean rooms. These are not engineers. TSMC moves people to Taiwan to train and work their hands on till they are ready. An AZ TSMC fab does not require the large number of engineers typically resident at a large fab in Taiwan. The difficult research work, recipe setup, analysis, and computationally intense design prep work Im certain will still be done in Taiwan. Further Complex equipment always has the manufacturers equipment engineers onsite. If there is a need to bring on board high level process and design engineers, the US has the best in the world. Its a myth that the us doesnt have them.

They had a drought in Taiwan a while ago and got really big in into water reclamation and recycling. It might be tricky initially, but I dont think it will be a problem in the long term. In Arizona, we will comply with local regulations and pursue similar industry design standards for water management. Two important aspects of our approach are water recycling and water reclamation At startup, approximately 65 of the water used in the Arizona operation will come from TSMCs inhouse water recycling systems. The recycled water will be used in systems such as our air scrubbers and cooling tower systems. To achieve our goal of 90 water reclamation, We will build an advanced water treatment facility Industrial Water Reclamation Plant at our Phoenix operation with a design goal of achieving Near Zero Liquid Discharge. This means the fabs will be capable of using nearly every drop of water back into the facility. This is a process of converting industrial wastewater into water that can be reused for a variety of purposes.

They always have. 22nm was bad yield. 14nm 2016 was bad yield Obviously newer nodes have worse yield. And those yields typically improve in a linear fashion until they reach limitations of equipment. But more specifically Intels yields often started poorly, were alleviated with improved design, and then the yields would catch up. 22nms first design had bad yields and saw frequency regression. The same is true for the first iteration of 14nm. We then saw awful yields and frequency regression with Intel 10nm. Later iterations of 90nm, 22nm, 14nm... All had great yields. But that was a few years after intitial production. Intels never been good at matching TSMCs yield improvement rate. Intel has suffered from yield issues throughout the 21st century due to a range of fundamental physics issues. Only EUV has helped surpass those limits. But EUV is expensive and takes longer to etch.

The typically statement indicates that that is speculation on the authors part and does not specify what the Broadcoms engineers actual concerns are. Not saying you are incorrect, however it is important to be able to differentiate the facts from inferences made.

The article explicitly stated that Broadcom received back wafers and dies which are defacto referred to as hot runs when you are testing out the yield of your design. Sometimes bad yield is due to bad design, but usually it is due to bad Foundry performance. In this case, the dies had enough defects that Broadcom was concerned about the viability of HVM production. Which means Broadcom should choose the guaranteed product from TSMC instead. Broadcom could obviously say fuck it and go with Intel, but that would defy literally all of history and logic.

Gelsinger happened. To be completely fair on Gelsinger though Intel was in a bad spot before he took over. Intel was behind its competition and had inferior products which put them behind. At least though the company was profitable and had decent cash flow. Now it doesnt even have that. When Gelsinger took over in the beginning of 2021 he basically said he wanted Intel to be a company that both designs chips and manufacturers them. He was extremely optimistic to investors about that plan and started making announcements of building big factories in Arizona, Ohio, Oregon, Germany, and other places. In their original forecast in 2021 Intel said that the factories would start being constructed in 2021 and be built in late 2025 and start producing. The main problem came that not even Intel foresaw was a complete earnings collapse. All of the money was basically going to capex to develop these factories and nothing was really going towards their existing products. Intel fell even further behind and their products became more undesirable and competitors moved even further ahead. It came to a point where margins collapsed and they are basically giving away their products for a small to no profit. They also took a massive loss on their chip fab machines cause they were crap so now they have to write them off and buy new ones from ASML. Now cause of the earnings collapse they have even less money to put towards these factories and have to use every financial trick in the book to get money to fund these. One they have been using is debt. Debt has ballooned but you can only take on so much debt. Another is issuing shares. Intel has been issuing shares quite substantially but that will only get you so far especially when your stock is selling off and not desirable as is. Another is selling their ownership stakes in their factories and spinning off other assets. They basically dumped Mobileye and now they want to dump Altera. Construction was also delayed and now Intel is saying that the factories now wont be ready until 2028 at the earliest. That also assumes no more delays. So their financial situation is only getting worse and worse and the fabs are not expected to have results until 20282030. Gelsingers plan only put Intel into an even worse spot then they were already in. Their financials have been the worst in decades, their stock price is at its lowest point in a long time, his promise of having results are looking even more bleak. Its not good.

Excellent question! IMO, the bear case could be triggered by 1. Supply chain challenges As I mentioned in the post, Blackwell is the most aggressive product roadmap in chip history. And chips are manufactured with a long supply chain with multiple players involved and dependencies in different products. Two products that are acting as the bottleneck right now are CoWoS packaging produced by TSMC and HBM3e memory done by Samsung and SK Hynix. Without this Blackwell chip cannot be produced. If these bottlenecks elevate or are not scaled up soon, NVIDIA would have to lose out on revenue 2. Power infrastructure Blackwell run data centers are power guzzlers. On the demand side hyperscalers, things are still not figured out as to how exactly will this power be supplied at scale. So any misses on power infrastructure build out might cause some risk as well

My thesis for NVDA is very simple Machine learningaccelerated computing MLAC is extraordinarily powerful, more so than anyone thought for the preceding decades before chatGPT the Alexnet surprise was met with criticism of the dataset well before acceptance of the methods, and that is already over a decade ago. MLAC outcomes are directly associated to scale nothing exciting happens at small scales, everything we will ever want is behind scalewalls read Suttons The Bitter Lesson. MLAC infrastructure at SOTA scales is an extraordinarily hard problem from every angle processingdesign, heat, energy, networking, manufacturing, assembly, etc. Those who wish to leverage the capabilities of MLAC and DO NOT want to deal with the infrastructure problem vastly outnumber those who would welcome the challenge basically only Mag7 will consider it, and the markets those who DO NOT want to deal with it are trying to address are essentially infinite cant list and count markets that dont exist and could never exist without the new technological capabilities MLAC unlocks. And NVDA has owned this moment not due to luck at least not due to luck to the extent that those who call them lucky believe Jensen et al have been squarely focused on this no later than alexnet and they used this conviction to spend serious manhoursresources developing for 0billion dollar markets. Cuda, omniverse, isaac lab, drive sim, etc. So when you consider the tangential opportunities this nextgen MLAC is growing towards we can just choose robotics as one example you have all these firms competing at the edge to be the first with the best solution dropin bluecollar replacements as the TAM of these applications is on the order of 100BT, NVDA is the only viable option, with all others requiring further efforts on the enduser that are irrelevant to their problem. Theres a reason pretty much every newly minted robotics firm is using NVDA robotics platforms. This is exactly why Google still buys so much NVDA they are squeezed by their endusers who demand the platforms NVDA has developed as the maturity of the platforms is directly related to the rate of progress they can make. If Google had the same ecosystem around their TPUs I would not be nearly as singularly bullish on NVDA as I am. NVDA is so far ahead here that even their competitor AMD isnt competing with them look at the earnings growth deltas between these two over the last 2 years it is an empircal truth the best kind of truth in MLAC. And for AMD to seriously compete, they would need to operate in a manner antithetical to how they operate read theyd need to spend billions on software development that their earnings cannot support. The reason AMD wins most console bids is the same reason they dont have the ecosystem they are a bargain option for those willing to do more software leg work. And there are a lot more opportunities than LLMs and Robots just try and count them. If matrix math is really the secret sauce here, the winner in the chip space will be whoever has the most plush redcarpet all the way to the endusers. And it will be a compounding win for at least 35 years due to the complexity of even existing in the space.

Pure chatbots are useless, yes. When they are useful, it is in combination with some other functionality like perplexity search or queries into pdfs. In the latter case there is already money being made. But these are edge cases. General public doesnt see past chatgpt and midjourney. The production of AI chips, the datacenters that allow to rent their computational capacity, and the actual training, execution and research using that capacity are three distinct strata of what is commonly called AI today. What I am saying is that in the latter layer generative AI is driving revenue into the two upper strata, but the likely result is generative AI wont be making any money on its own, but only when it is applied to solve useful problems, and that there are other, nongenerative applications that can now use the capacity to solve real problems which cant be solved with linear, algorithmic methods and which previously couldnt be solved because the brute computational capacity had a high barrier of entry. By spending on capex, datacenters allow others to use AI as opex.

Youd expect more based on your current knowledgepast experience. Ai is uncharted waters so those dynamics dont really apply. Ai is an exploratory expedition into uncharted waters, not just a point A to point B container ship of sneakers.

Going to redirect to ChatGPT because it will answer the question in far more detail than I ever could The behavior youre describing aligns with what some people refer to as swing trading, which involves holding a stock for a short period days to weeks to capitalize on expected price movements. Its different from day trading, where traders buy and sell stocks within the same day, often executing multiple trades in a single day. Many retail investors might buy and hold stocks for short or long periods based on their strategy, market outlook, or financial goals. When you see people talking about buying, holding, or selling specific stocks, they could be Day Traders Buying and selling stocks within the same trading day to profit from small price fluctuations. Swing Traders Holding stocks for a few days to weeks, aiming to profit from shortterm market movements. LongTerm Investors Buying and holding stocks for months or years, focusing on the companys growth or dividends rather than shortterm price changes. Your plan to buy a stock and sell it after a couple of weeks fits more with swing trading. Many people engage in this type of trading to get a taste of the market or to try and make shortterm profits. If you proceed, keep in mind the following Transaction Costs Ensure the potential profit is more than the trading fees, if applicable. Tax Implications In a taxable brokerage account, selling a stock within a year could subject you to shortterm capital gains tax, which is typically higher than longterm capital gains tax. Market Risk Stock prices can be unpredictable in the short term, and your expected profit might not materialize. If this approach appeals to you, youre not alonemany people test the waters of the stock market this way.

Anecdotally reading some old posts from here on Snowflake from people way more knowledgeable about the data warehousingdata engineering space than I, it seems like more people like Databricks more than Snowflake. Plus watching some videos on the subject, it seems like Microsofts Fabric could be a threat to both companies. But then again, it seems like most companies pay for a variety of tools in this space so perhaps the FUD about SNOW is potentially unfounded. But still, I think valuation in the face of competition and margin pressure is a concern.
Data stacks last only as long as the leadership over it lasts. When they change it changes.

I acknowledge my ignorance on the subject. But even if competitors products arent as competitive or as good as Snowflakes, they can always offer a discount on volume or force Snowflake to lower their prices so that Snowflake can retain them as a customer. Margin compression for a company that isnt profitable on GAAP basis with huge SBC and is priced at 10x revenue doesnt mean the stock has much room to run.
There has been crazy exec turnover across all companies these days. How often do you hear about tech stacks getting replaced?

Good, Im glad you at least rolled that one back. And yes, competitors can always offer discounts and its a great tactic especially for the cloud vendors. Luckily for Snowflake, AWS doesnt have a great product for the largest enterprises to use so the customer would have to switch to GCP or Azure. If youre a global company, I find it unlikely youre successfully running on BQ or Fabric at scale although the technology on both has improved. I read from an insider that Google are actually shifting away from BQ product investments to focus fully on AI which is good for SNOW. Regardless, GCP and Azure are far behind in the cloud race compared to AWS. Completely agree on SBC. Slootman ruined the progress and momentum of the company with this and bad hiring. 10x revenue valuation is tiny in the big dataAI space so I dont get the concern there when they are on the high side of growth rates and customer satisfaction. Also, they havent projected their new product revenue into their guidance yet. This could add an additional 100M to revenue this year. Might not be a moonshot but its certainly not the downfall of a company like the short sellers want you to believe so you sell the stock.
By tech stacks I mean things like snowflake, data bricks, synapse, redshift. It happens quite a bit in healthcare

give me some examples. I find it hard to believe that large enterprises with all their mission critical data carefully organized and tagged would be willing to throw it all away and start over again with a new vendor just to save 10 on the bill. The migration costs and business risks far outweigh the benefit

Ive been trading OXY since last fall. Buffett likes them and holds 255 million shares. Hes been buying more recently when the price has been in the high 50s. Buffett also has a huge cash pile, so it stands to reason that Buffett will continue to buy more shares if the price drops. That should help create a floor. Today I sold the 57 put with the 823 expiration date. I got 0.37 in premium and the trade lasts one week. So I divide the 0.37 in premium by the 57 strike and I get 0.0065. Then I multiply that by 52, because Im risking the money for one week, and I could do a trade similar to this on this or another company 52 times over the course of a year. And I get an annualized return of 33. Im doing this with one tranche of what Im willing to put into OXY, and I already have three tranches of OXY with a total cost basis of 52.74 per share. This put option reduces my cost basis down to 52.62 per share. If I get assigned the shares at 57 Ill collect the dividend on 910, then sell a covered call at the 57 strike. Heres an example

When you do restructuring, it usually costs you more in the year you do it than you save in payrollbecause of severance, job placement services, higher unemployment insurance costs, etc. Then you consider the increases in turnover and reduced engagement, and the costs are even higher because youre spending more rehiring for roles youre keepingbecause people jump ship from being afraid of more layoffs, employees are less productive, etc. It makes way more sense to implement hiring freezes in which hiring require upper management approval and relying on churn to reduce headcount. Broad layoffs only really make sense if youre looking to axe a project entirely, and arent able to place workers somewhere else.

Just as a matter of portfolio allocation The first 20 of your bond portfolio should be in long term treasuries Also, should there be a flight to safety for one reason or another, investors should flock to Treasuries in general, usually including long term treasuries, or at least it seems to have been the case during the run into the Covid19 Crash in March 2020, Im sure you can find a chart of around that time you sound like a chart guy. My general thesis is just everyone is wrong about inflation, and we are careening into outright deflation, as a result of the yield curve being inverted for this long, destroying dollars as people pay their debts back, that other people need to pay their debts like a game of musical chairs, and therefore there should be eventually massive defaults and unemployment, and thus deflation. Because The Fed uses the unemployed as a buffer stock unemployment must go up, that is The Feds job. With this much public debt, as interest rates go down, that income that will go away will be bondholders income which will be deflationary, and no one will want to borrow still probably now simply because prices are still just crazy, and we will have to start bailing out entities on the fiscal side, so the trade will go fast. Also The liquidity trap Tldr inflation will probably be a nonissue, although, fiscal policy could really screw things up for this trade, which seems to be the case. The only thing I got lucky on was that I mostly loaded into FRNs as a hedge which seems to have been almost the right move outside of prehaving a bunch of Ibonds back then before moving on it or Id be straight fucked, I was far too early, and really believed they would never actually raise rates, and just keep threatening to lol. But now that rates have gone up, and are now finally coming down, things have only actually gotten crazier and crazier. So who knows. I was also trying to barbell a portfolio of bitcoin and 30 year treasuries to min max returns, they moved far more correlated than I had liked they wound up both going down, though at one point I could have sold my bonds for more than my bitcoins had dropped, I should have just took the 15 arbitrage and left the trade then, Im now down 50 on my TLTBTC trade, at least the gains have outweighed the losses the bonds though, and the interest on my FRNs eclipsed my losses as well as a function of how glacially long this trade has taken, so it still kinda all worked. All that to say, just buying SPY probably would have been less heartache for pretty much the same result, and much better for my mental health as things just keep getting crazier and crazier. lol Although, maybe matching it with bonds and bitcoins is a feat in itself, who knows.

The mechanics of one of the largest and liquid traded securities in the world is nothing like GME or BBBY. Youre right, its worse actually. I dont quite remember the details on that front though to be honest, it wasnt the primary motivation for the trade, the primary motivation is the monetary system is having a persistently hard time maintaining inflation as a result of being broken in some way I suspect too high global demand for dollars relative to the amount we need to actually print and distribute to satisfy the implications of the Triffin dilemma with our position as the global reserve currency. Allegedly when people short things like TLT, I recall it is actually pretty dangerous Ill try to dig up why. I didnt hear no bell. To think it will behave like those did is a fools errand I would implore you to look what was going on with it into the March 2020 crash, it most certainly can behave that way. When people think the world is ending, one way or another, theyll be back, and I will be there ready to sell. It is not natural for the yield curve to be inverted this long.

Im not all in anything, I am mostly in FRNs though still. I also didnt hear no bell. It is not natural for short term rates to be above long term rates. what next, short squeeze and quadruple witching on TMF ? I assert, the speculators are those shorting TLT and betting interest rates are going to keep going up in line with The Fed holding up the short end of the curve expecting it to normalize, not me. Long term rates must go down, because the monetary system needs more larger longer loans. Im probably not wrong overall, the market is just more irrational and likely more fraudulent than most people expect. Im betting I can stay liquid longer than the market can remain irrational. Shit, Ill sell some FRNs and buy more TLT. My average price is currently only 114.17, I can get it down really easily here. Just another 1000 shares will put it down to 106.79, 5000 would bring me down to 98.40, those are exitable, especially when investors realize how fucked shit is, it is only a matter of time, and it isnt exactly the sort of trade you can chase when it happens. You have to already have the position. Slap those badboys together, and swap them to percent change from a year ago. It wouldnt surprise me if long term rates went to 0 is all Im saying, and neither should you be, it should unwind those who were holding onto cheap mortgages increasing supply of housing although, if it gets as bad as I think, no one is going to want to borrow anyways to relieve those trying to in mass sell, for obvious reasons. They have to go low enough to get people to borrow and spend in a big way, and they have to go much much lower, lower than they were previously to accomplish that I hope. Its also the reason Im not worried about real estate prices or speculators or institutions allegedly buying up houses, I think a lot of people are in for a lot of heartache when their overpriced house isnt worth what they had hoped. I wish them good luck.

replies.text: historical data has shown that dividend paying stocks tended to outperform their non dividend paying counterparts. If dividends dont inherently add value, why is this the case? Life is not just about numbers. And the differences between dividend payments and stock buybacks involve a great deal more than math. Dividends are usually distributed in a systematic way, and cutting dividend payments is seen as a very bad sign. So, a dividend is in effect a statement by management that they believe the company can perform and continue to deliver into the future. Boeing is a case study. Prior to 1998 investment in new aircraft programs and the companys reputation was seen as a way to protect investors, and the dividend, well into the future. Post 1998 the Jack Welch school that came to control the company was focused on short term results and stock buybacks. The difference between Boeing today and what is called in the industry legacy Boeing is stark.

This is well documented but too often ignores the behavioral story. You touch on the misconceptions in your final paragraph. But perhaps they know themselves. By that I mean there are people for whom dividends have psychological benefits, meaning the ability to hold equity at all is improved by knowing the dividends are coming in.
In certain countries like Australia dividends have special treatment from a tax perspective also, which makes it an attractive component of total return.

What about people who are in distribution. Doesnt having some focus not total focus on quality stocks that are divided players help with cash flow during periods where sequence of return risk would be detrimental

Its a nice thought experiment, but youre taking it too far in your conclusions. Assumptions like management will always spend money in good faith to maximize earnings are useful if you want to make a world that is spreadsheetcompatible, but massively off the mark from the real world. In the real world management has incentives like getting the stock price to a certain number by a certain time to get a payout, future be damned. Creating unrealistic narratives about future earning to justify or increase PE ratios you know are excessive. Tech is a huge part of the SP500 and these problems are very common in tech. Around the dotcom crash this all got so bad that nobody could give out any dividends at all, for fear of demonstrating that they dont have endless golden geese lined up that the money would be better spent on. These days theyve gotten a little better about this and your Apple, Microsoft, and Google at least pay out a nominal dividend of like 0.51. Investors regularly get their money pissed up the wall like this in tech, when they would have been much better off just receiving it as a dividend than having tens of billions wasted on the metaverse with promises that all life would revolve around this concept in a few years, only to have them say actually never mind its all fake after a few years of stock options vesting at high valuations. Of course, were in the middle of a similar bubble with AI, so this all seems quaint now, but trust me, in a few years there will be a lot of people saying I wish they had just given me the money. So yeah, I like a small dividend, just to maintain a culture that this is my money they are playing with, and if they dont have a good use for it then Ill take it. A lot of this applies to share buybacks as well, although theyre prone to more bad incentives as they work through share price, so management is incentivized to do them even when the stock is already overvalued, and the personal incentives mentioned above etc.
Are dividend payouts on average less volatile than stock prices?

What you said is true. However dividend stocks typically fit in the Value category and they do have substantially different characteristics than growth stocks. Generally larger older companies with less volatility and more predictable cash flows or they wouldnt be paying dividends. So if you are trying to make the point that only younger faster growing growth stocks are the only thing you should invest in I would call you Wrong.

Part of the reason for dividends is they discipline management through requiring payouts and ensures they dont squander the companies cash. This is covered more in finance classes under treasury operations than capital structure. However, I think its a valid reason for dividends. True you may not want a fast growing company to pay dividends and instead invest in growth. However, most companies dont fall into that category and would likely waste extremely large investments. I guess you could make an argument for stock buybacks since they are more tax efficient but because they are expected at regular intervals they dont quite have the same ability to discipline management.

However, dividends themselves are an irrelevant criterion for investment selection. thats not what Modigliani and Miller claimed. Their research has been consistently distorted and misrepresented over the years. Note that MM didnt say that dividends were irrelevant they said, under their extremely narrow conditions, that dividend payout ratios should be irrelevant to the overall value of the firm. That is a specific finance claim, not a generalized disregard for dividend payments. It is not what MM said its what people now think they said. Theres a big difference. Daniel Peris, The Ownership Dividend Routledge, 2024
The payout of dividends is derisking. You could ride a growth stock all the way up and then all the way down with nothing to show for it.
