VOO 10 year fidelity stats 13.34 with 1.29 dividend SCHD 10 year fidelity stats 11.71 with 3.29 dividend The difference in total average return is 1.52, which is roughly the same difference between their dividend payout. The whole growthtotal returndividend drama is unnecessary and really only applies to high yield or yield max dividend products.

Empirical evidence, such as the drop in stock prices on the exdividend date, supports this theory. When a dividend is paid, the share price tends to decrease by the amount of the dividend, as cash leaving the company is reflected by a reduction in book value per share. Thats not just just a market tendency, its whats required to happen. All opening bids and offers are adjusted down by the amount of the dividend and any shareholders at the open are entitled to the dividend.

The Dividend Irrelevance Theory, proposed by Modigliani and Miller MM in 1961, asserts that dividend policy has no impact on a firms value or cost of capital in a frictionless market. The Dividend Irrelevance Theory, proposed by Modigliani and Miller MM in 1961, asserts that dividend policy has no impact on a firms value or cost of capital in a frictionless market. Under this theory, a companys value is determined solely by its earnings power and investment decisions, not by how it distributes its profits. Whether profits are retained or distributed, the firms underlying valuation remains the same. I highlighted the key phrase in that paragraph you wrote. That lines says taxes, law changes, wares, natural disasters, and diseases, and criminal activity are Irrelevant. Clearly that is not the case if you look through history. The resent a pandemic and hurricanes and Russias invasion of Ukraine have all had massive impacts on society and many businesses did not survive. Looking further back Enron was seen as a great investment until it was people discovered that the executives lied about the companies performance and illegally manipulated energy prices in california. A tariff war was initiated by US government in 1929 resulted in in an about 60 drop in trade and the SP500 loosing 13 of it value in about 2 days. Add in WW2 and the economy needed 14 years to recover. That one assumption in the theory make it it invalid. Things beyond the control of the company can quickly turn it from profitable to a money looser and eventually kill the company. Look at the dividend return and capital gains earnings of the SP500 seperately 74 of of the funds performance comes from reinvesting the dividends Only 26 came from capital gains. Clearly the dividends from the index, as small as it is, are important. Clearly the divided irrelevance theory is not a valid theory. this video also explains the problems with the theory.

Everything you say is true but investing is a personal situation driven game. During your accumulation phase you would be wrong to have any allocation other than a diversified portfolio that is spread between growth and value with some adjustment for whether we are in a Value or a Growth phase in the market. In the Early Accumulation phase you should be heavily invested in equities as you dont much care about down cycles as you have little money at risk. In the late accumulation phase you start to build in a strategy for up and down markets as you now have some principal to protect. In the Preretirement stage you start to worry more about beta and less about alpha particularly if you have done a good job of accumulation. In Retirement your goals are preservation and income, so less beta is more important than excess alpha unless you are late to the party. Assuming you have hit your goals, then joining rdividend and forgetting a growth allocation makes total sense. In that stage assuming a good number, you can use the dividends and leave the kids the equities at whatever value they may have when you are gone. People throw around a 45 wdl number which is doable with a dividend stream and no stock sales if you pick your stocks correctly.

Id actually argue that all else equal, dividends are actually a structural headwind to returns. As you point out, dividends are just a mandatory liquidation of a portion of the market cap of the company. Any investor who owns the stock via a basket e.g. an index fund investor who reinvests dividends is effectively going short the stock vs long the other stocks in the basket and actually reinvesting an even smaller portion than they would have otherwise because the dividend reduces the companys weight in the index. Extending the work of Koijen et al, this imbalanced flow should have a lasting price impact on the stock relative to the other constituents in excess of the fundamental change in the value of the companys assets

Yes, because in the real world no two companies are identical. The stock price drops momentarily, but the cashflows that lead to a dividend payment will generate more cashflows. I personally know of a Tesla holder who became a millionaire ON PAPER, who is now under water and will likely remain so for a long while. I dont hold single stocks myself other than BRK.B, and am fine with no dividends from it because I trust the process there. Total returns and opportunity cost is an excel exercise. Lets look at it another way say you buy a property to rent, but because you want to avoid the taxes on income you leave it empty until it appreciates enough for your liking to sell. How does this sound?

What? Most of that sounds like a case for paying dividends, not buying back shares. Im not at all saying a company should hoard cash or that all attempts at corporate growth are warranted or feasible. Share buybacks are just gaming EPS metrics. They were long an illegal form of market manipulation that Reagans admin legalized, and theyve since been heavily incentivized by executive compensation structures that exacerbate wealth inequality. The highly compensated with stock options in their large taxable accounts want buybacks to reduce their own tax footprints while its clawed back through corporate taxes that affect those with tax advantaged accounts as well. Its CEO subsidy. Tax efficiency, maybe, but for whom? Who then gets to pay for it? Its also not more efficient at returning value to investors given that companies are buying back shares when theyre overvalued to achieve all of that. There are times when share repurchases make sense, but not as a replacement for dividends.
Yeah. But I have never heard of a big company CEO without a big pay package.

If youre holding more cash than you should hold, do something with it and stop holding more cash than you need. Now you dont have a bunch of extra cash sitting around. The decision of what specifically to do with it is unrelated to not wanting to hold excess cash.

Then your dividend stock had higher returns, so its not an apples to apples comparison. And again, you can sell any time you want if you want distribution and youre not bound by the companys schedule. Also, why are you taking out money in one case and not the other? That should be based on YOUR financial situation, not the companys. If you reinvest the dividends, you go to zero again.

A stock could go to 0, but if you held it for 10 years at a 5 dividend, you have 50 of your investment as a return of capital. If there was no current pay and it goes to 0, you have nothing If the stock price was flat for 10 years, you would get 50. But if its a slow decline like with some former dividend kings then you would get much less than 50 of your original investment.
So just say yes I believe dividends produce grater total returns. Its not true, but its what youre saying in way more words.

I mean I guess technically your return is higher with the dividend stock, but that feels like semantics in a scenario where both stocks go to 0 and go out of business. Dividends represent forced capital return, they take the psychology of trying to guess when to sell out of the equation. You dont have to time it, youre derisking your investment. And maybe I want to keep my equity for the upside, but at a lower effective cost basis. I work in private credit and recapitalize businesses all the time in dividend recap transactions where PE literally takes on expensive debt just to take money off the table. The only benefit for them is derisking their investment by returning capital, they are actually destroying equity value with the debt service but its worth it to them to take money off the table.

No, not saying that, I am saying that total return is a factor of price movement and income, but of these two one is real and in your hands and the other needs an action to materialize, otherwise its just looking at graphs. Edit the only situation you can accurately compare total returns in the real world is by putting something like VWCE and VWRL side by side, and estimating taxation. In that case they will be exactly identical before tax, and different depending on each countrys tax system, eg in Switzerland where I live theyll be identical because real or estimated dividends are taxed the same. In other countries VWCE may come out on top. I am fully aware of all that. I just prefer VWRL because I want to see that somethings happening. Its psychological.

You would be knowledgable on a subject then, perhaps you can answer it. My understanding is, your actual numerical value of debt is essentially irrelevant provided you have the cashflow to make a lender comfortable. Is this ballpark accurate?

Correct. The most common way a lender will look at the quantum of debt they are willing to extend is a multiple on cash flow. So if you generate 100m in cash flow a year, a lender will most likely be willing to extend 300 400m or 3 to 4x cash flow. The primary reason being is a company will trade at some much higher multiple say 7 to 20 times depending on business so if youre only lent 3 to 4, you are safely inside a potential EV of the company. Secondarily, the lender wants to ensure you generate enough cash flow to cover the interest expense of the debt. There are other underwriting metholdogies though, multiple on recurring revenue or pure asset based lending against liquidation value of assets are two other common ones

The key here is that you want to retire early. Think about the age youd like to retire at and the amount youd like to have savedinvested at that point. Then think about how much you plan to spend in retirement per month and how youre going to cover it investment dividendsincome, etc. Once you have those calculations you can see how much you have to investsave per year to meet that goal. If youre significantly behind on that glide slope, your answer is probably to invest it in index funds or however you see fit to invest. If you think youre ahead of that plan, you can use it to acquire a passive income yielding asset like an investment property that can help towards that retirement spend. Good luck!

First, did you both inherit it or did you inherit it. If you mingle inherited funds with family funds they become family funds. In Canada inherited funds are normally immune to divorce proceedings, which while your marriage is happy now, could change in the future. Your best bet would be to open a TFSA and use up any remaining room you the persons who inherited it have, the rest should go into a registered account and moved over to the TFSA every year. Both of these accounts should be dedicated to just the inheritance. Topping up an RESP or RRSP are also an option. In the future you may find a use for the money, and at that point you can pull it out of the accountTFSA and the gains in the TFSA are tax free.

Dont rent out your home. You think youll make passive monthly income, but you wont. Instead youll be a landlord or pay a property manager to halfass manage it for you. You have to fight with your home warranty to get any big expense items covered... and there will be a lot. When a tenant moves in all of a sudden everything breaks... theres a leak coming from the tub, the fridge isnt cold enough, the AC unit needs to be replaced. Its laborious and expensive. Also, the monthly rent will count as income, which could push you into another tax bracket. You can write off expenses which is a plus, but chances are at the end of the year you will barely breakeven. And then of course you never know what kind of tenant youll get but one thing is for sure, even the best tenant in the world will not treat your home the way you would.

The way to secure your retirement is to focus on your distribution stream, not just how big your bucket o is. Unknown to most people because they require a sizable amount up front and therefore arent marketed by your typical retail insurance salesperson, there are taxfreeyield life insurance policies that the wealthy have used for years to generate and perpetuate wealth. Good read on this is What Would the Rockefellers Do? How the Wealthy Get and Stay That Way by Garrett Gunderson. Besides income off them being tax free, its not subject to the whims of the stock market. I invested a for me good sized inheritance this way and am very happy with my decision, especially when I listen to my siblings who took the typical investment route always going on about whatever the stock market is doing. Of course there are many who can advise you but I got my education on this from thebreakaway league.com site has excellent videos and other explanatory resources.

The best advice is to start up a small business on the side and transition to doing it full time when you no longer have the ability to work both your other job and run your business. One thing for certain is you need to fit your skills into a business where there is a market for a service or product that you can facilitate. You dont start a business because thats what you know how to do. If there is not a definite need for it you are wasting your time and money.

Because growth of 529 plans is not taxed if the funds are used for education. You can get a rough projection on how much college will cost for your kid and then set this up so it just compounds tax free for 18 years. We put a large sum of money into Amex national savings bank 175k. I just received an email the rate is dropping from 4.5 to 4.1. Currently earning over 500month in interest. Opened it online. Transferred money from my regular bank. It was available that day. Needed to transfer money in a hurry because we bought a house and finalized a closing date sooner than expected. The job security thing definitely factors in, as does where you live, if you owe any debt, and how much you typically spend per month. If you live in a high cost of living area, such as NY or SF, it can be much harder to find a job if you lose yours, yet you still have to keep paying off your bills. Even jobs that seem easy to find a new one can be difficult to find, depending on where you live, because in big business cities, the pool of people searching for jobs is always vast and theres always people more qualified than you. So ideally, you dont want to be jobless for six months or more, but if it were to come to that, then youd be prepared. And if it didnt and you were only out of a job for 13 months, you still have 35 months of emergency money leftover as a security net.

Wanted to chime in here and say that you should back yourself if you land on a solid idea which youve thought out well and truly believe in. Like with any investment, you have to accept the risk associated with it. Could you potentially start again from square one if you lose whatever money you invest? If the answer is no, shelf the business venture for the time being. If the answer is yes, then I have a success story to keep you inspired... My uncle moved to Hong Kong when he was 20 during national military service. He moved from a rural village in France with virtually no practical experience in business. Irrespective of this, he started his first business and worked super hard and really believed in his vision, despite being broke for a long time. He failed many times. His relentlessness is something that should be studied. Anyway, one of his ideas paid off and he became the richest French man in Hong Kong back in the mid 2000s. Its absolutely doable. Of course there is a massive amount of luck involved. And I wont quibble with anyone that addresses the fact we live in a different time now, however starting a business and being successful can without a doubt allow you to achieve your dreams. One thing I will say your dream has to be to run a successful business, not just to get rich quick and chill. I spent some time working for him as a kid and observed some of his business practices. The key ones were 1. Take small steps. Seems painfully simple but this is often something people forget to do. They get over excited with an idea and allow themselves to make silly, costly errors. These errors can really take the wind out of your sails and sales. 2. It all comes down to your margins. To be successful every dollar has to be accounted for. Eking out every cent you can in areas which seem frivolous may make all the difference later on. Not putting the hard graft in now will always cost you somewhere down the line. 3. Be lucky! A lot of what running a successful business comes down to is hard work. Its also important to be clever with how you manage several overarching areas of your business e.g funding, costing, manufacturing, if required, marketing, sales etc. But sometimes it does just come down to being in the right place at the right time. Like with my uncle, he was in the right place at the right time and it paid off massively. Of course he might argue he was there by design, so maybe its more in our power than we realise . The trick to this is to always be in a position to take an opportunity in business if it presents itself. To achieve this, you must live and breathe your business. Know your shit and try not to get scammed too many times when starting out trust your gut, youll soon realise if you have the stomach for business or not. This is all anecdotal, of course its not proof that anyone will certainly make it. Its simply a reminder that running a successful business makes it possible. Either way, dont half shoot it. Really tear off a chunk of whatever you decide to do. Theres no use in half arsing it.

Theres a lot of private REIT offerings that often label themselves as some variation of a unique opportunity previously only available to rich people! But they generally wind up being worse than a REIT and also more complex to own, are illiquid entirely illiquid or limited opportunities to sell and some in the past have gated withdrawals for temporary periods. This seems like it framed itself differently but seems very gimmicky in terms of the kind of things you got and has the same core issues limited liquidity, etc. Never heard of the company mentioned but crowdfunding, EREITs which feel like what were previously nontraded REITs an asset class that lead to a lot of complaints over the years in a different wrapper, stuff like that I just really dont recommend. Edit The site is kind of underwhelming. It focuses on the message which is nice but who is running the operation and what is their background? I see some people listed but no biographybackground. It shows the number of properties it owns in Atlanta but no examples that I can see. Apparently this is some sort of RegA nontraded REIT theres just very little information from an investment standpoint on the website, which is focused entirely on the message really. Id have to really go through filings to try to have a better understanding of the investment yes the message is nice but what do these houses look like? who is running this and what kind of qualifications do they have? the CEO of this was apparently previously CEO of some sort of automotive company?, which imo shouldnt have to be done. What are the specifics of withdrawals, given limited liquidity? Is there the ability to gate withdrawals? It doesnt really say on the website. Looking at one of the filing offerings, theres a long list of risks including our manager and its affiliates have no prior experience managing a portfolio of assets to comply with REIT requirements and detailed conflicts of interest between the manager and the sponsor. Edit finally found it after looking through filings. They intend to limit the number of units to be able to be redeemed during any calendar year to 5 of the weighted average number of units outstanding during the prior year. The manager can gate withdrawals at any time, without notice, for any reason or no reason. Theres a lot of other specifics, but its like all the other nontraded REITs yes there is quarterly liquidity, but not if a lot of people try to redeem at once. Again, not really familiar with this beyond just starting to look through filings, but I just think that anything investmentwise needs to have more information than this does on its website. These kinds of offerings sell themselves very basically on their websites but imo theres a lot more to it I mean, just looking at one of the offering filings its nearly 100 pages and theres a lot of noteworthy thingsrisksconsiderations on these filings that should be under an FAQ section on the website itself, not something that people have to go through a filing to find when considering this sort of investment.
The ROOTS program is aimed at a poor demographic in the Atlanta area.

replies.text: You will never find anyone who endorses FAs on Reddit. The truth is a good FA can add value in places outside of the portfolio piece if youre with the right people they will take care of your estate planning, run tax efficient strategies tax loss harvesting, QCDs, Roth conversions, etc, and ultimately give you back your time otherwise spent researching, rebalancing, doing the tax loss harvesting yourself, etc. Is 1 worth the 24 weeks per year you spend working this stuff yourself? If no, then forgo the advisor. If yes, then find a CFPCFA that you like and that will do all of the above.

There is only an upside if you are clueless about andor uninterested in learning how to manage money, and would otherwise keep it all in the bank. 1.25 AUM is obscene, but more critically it means youll have a safe withdrawal rate of 2.75 instead of 4. Do you want that? Hard pass on this down to Earth guy hes not auditioning to be your friend. actually worse due to suboptimal, high expense investments vs. basic index funds
Dont need one. Job should be nuked. Its the ultimate nepotism job

Unless youre clueless or actively harming yourself by your trading behavior, the worth its anything to do with portfolio composition or returns. What your paying for is management, running projections, advice on tax efficientcy and withdraw strategies, etc. 99.9 of people dont need these services on an ongoing basis and it would be far less expensive to pay someone as needed when there are significant changes in your circumstances.

You didnt mention how much you have in investments but say you have 5mm, at 1.25 management fees thats 62,500 per year. If you really want to hire an advisor then pay by the hour rather than them managing the whole portfolio. A simple mix of equity index funds and Treasury Inflation Protected Securities would suffice for your portfolio which certainly doesnt require paying 1.25 in management fees a year.

Speaking as a PM, they should only really be used for funds, things that are very complex andor extremely sensitive, or for people who really have no idea what theyre doing and need the help. This precludes a lot of individual investors.

This question has been asked alot. You need a wealth manager, not really a portfolio manager. Wealth managers maximize returns while minimizing tax burdens. They also can help create a budget and plan for future expenses. The last thing is trust. This is the hardest thing retirees need to get their heads around. Your entrusting your older years to a complete stranger and that is very hard. Remember, the wealth manager needs to earn your trust and listen to you when you call with questions. Ive seen people pull millions away from managers that have performed fantastic, because they would not return a call. Plus you dont need to give them your entire nest egg. Let them prove they can do what they say.

Heres the thing. This sub HATES advisors because they think all they do is buy stocks and not beat the market, which isnt what a goodcompetent FAs job really is, so youre not going to get many biased answers. What you should be looking for is someone who will manage your money while constructing an indepth finical plan help with estate planning and manage your tax liability.
The portfolio you gave is a bit worrying. I would suggeest an hourly fee based advisor

My wife and I have a multiple 7 figure net worth. Our FA firm fee only CFP handles all our tax paperwork including representing us if the IRS comes knocking, asset rebalancing, estate planning, helped set up our POAs, wills, trust paperwork, does our IRARoth conversions for us, manages our inherited IRA RMDs, helps us manage our benefit elections, set up all our 529 accounts for the kidsextended family and opened the doors to some accredited investor only investments that are looking to return 2030 or more per year. They have more than earned their fees so far and they make it a point of emphasis to make sure we are comfortable with all the choices and decisions before moving forward.
Hope your best of the bunch brought lube. Those fees are high. You could use vanguard if you even need a FA. Vanguard charges .03 AUM

OK, let me rephrase that they are not worth it in terms of which stocks to invest in, but rather as a lifecoach that tells its client to do things more fundamental try to sock away all you can in your 401K IRA, have a certain mix of cash and stocks, etc. But this is something that one can get for free by listening to Dave Ramsey or Suzi or reading a book by them. I suppose that some folks are so weakwilled that they need to fork over a nice chunk of change to someone to tell them the same thing that those gurus do so as to motivate them to actually do it in a sunkcost fallacy type of way.

I think handling keys to your portfolio isnt a paranoia, particularly for independent advisors. Even if you deal with someone reputable, you are unlikely to know well how they approach IT security. For the net performance of 5.12, I think you answered yourself. There are good fixed income opportunities paying you above that.

I used to be in your position once I understood Behavioral Finance and read a white paper by Vanguard on why those with advisors make in avg 3 more annually and realized it.... Buy and hold might work when your young but as you reduce your risks when older you want to have professional advice

This sub hates advisors because they think their only job is to beat the SP. A good advisor at an RIA will be doing far more than investing your money, especially as you near retirement. On the investing side, theyll work with you to create an allocation that fits your risk tolerance. Of course you wont beat the SP over time when youre not 100 equity, but its a myth that managers cannot beat their respective index. Other than investing, theyll work with you on financial planning, tax planning, estate planning, and any questions you have. Many RIAs will have a fee under 1 for 1M plus portfolios.

But...1 is too high for a 7 figure portfolio. Im an FA btw for 30 years. Without telling you my fees, Id suggest 65 bps would be fair for the average client that just needs portfolio construction and ongoing ajustingrebalancing as the world turns, along with the usual questions about distributions and tax planning. Its not that hard, but even smart people have valid questions that a good FA can help with. 1 plus .25 is still nuts. Also, its a fee, not a commission, but you hopefullyprobably know that difference. Commissions died many years ago, unless youre an insurance agent.
Exactly my point as well.

replies.text: Absolutely set up a revocable living trust. Absolutely talk to an estate attorney to get one set up. You can set it up in a way that they only get portions of the trusts contents in stages. Say, for example, 50 at age 30 and the remainder at age 40. Or 13 at 30, 12 of remaining at 40, remaining at 50. Whatever you wanna do.

Lifetime exemption is 13.61mm for each kid. If you can afford to do that then why dont you go hire someone to avoid some estate taxes. I have custodial brokerages for my kids, and I bought muni bonds in each of them, plus some equities. As far as I can tell they wont be paying taxes on the muni bonds, and neither will I, nor will it add to my AGI. Im happy with that.

One method that we have used with our kids is funding Roth IRA contributions for them annually. Also, Ive talked to my kids a lot about money over the years and they now all have their own brokerage accounts with portfolios of funds. Some of the money came from their earnings and some came as gifts from us. Theyre all age 1821 and I dont really worry about any of them making stupid decisions with money. We also made the decision that we want them all to be selfsufficient people who understand what it means to earn a living rather than just being trust fund kids, so the dollars we have given them to this point isnt really enough for them to live comfortably on. Finally, check your state laws regarding UTMA accounts. In some states the age at which the accounts transfer to the minor is over 18 it is 21 here.

With kids you want to account for Worst case scenario normal best case scenario Worst case scenario you die or both parents die tomorrow. LI, guardianship short and long term physical legal and financial, annual stipends, when can kids access money. Best case scenario All the above but estate is huge. Some xtra tax considerations

A commonly overlooked but easy to access area is thinking about your own Roth IRA as a wealth transfer tool. Some things to consider You can use backdoor for both you and your spouse. Check if your work has a mega backdoor too. Per spouse you may be able to stuff 69kyear into it. Since you will have enough for your own retirement dont draw from the Roth IRA. Just let it keep growing tax free from the point of contribution. There are no minimum required distributions even when you are well into retirement age so it can keep growing. When either spouse passes it goes to the other but let it keep going. Finally when the last spouse passes the kids can inherit it.... AND THEN they can let it keep growing tax free for another 10 years. So you get essentially step up and continuous growth tax free on a packed area of wealth transfer Plus if things dont work out perfectly well you can still spend it for yourself in retirement if you want or need to.

I would definitely contact a trust and estates attorney. You do not want to hand the keys to the kingdom to young adults. That doesnt mean you cant help them get on their feet. I assume youre already using a 529. That provides you with tax benefits. If youre saving for college anyway why not? They are young enough that it would provide you with tax benefits on the capital gains. I would put in at least as much as the state tax benefits give you. You could open a custodial account for their gifts. Whenever a grandparent or friends give them cash, you can put some away. After a while their account will grow and it teaches them the value of saving a part of their gift. You could also gift to a trust. This is where the estate attorney comes in. Im not sure what trust type is best for your family. Maybe a grantor trust. In any case whatever you gift them is out of your estate. In 2026, the lifetime exemptions change and will most likely be halved unless congress does something. If that were to occur it makes sense to move money out of your estate now and let the returns compound outside of your estate. Depending on how much money youre saving you could easily pass the lower lifetime exemptions. Of course if you spend most of your income this wont be a problem. I would recommend for you to avoid getting advice on Reddit lol I know Im on here. Go hire a professional financial advisor and a trustestate attorney. It will be worth the money. Im saying this as a professional advisor of high net worth individuals who all have a team of advisors lawyer, tax and investments that work together. While you didnt grow up with a network the fact is you have become successful enough that you should hire professionals to take care of your needs.

This is the way.. And you dont have to be filthy rich to take advantage of it. My family got it done and included our home in the trust for 1000 fee. By move out of your estate, I mean not taxed as part of your estate when you pass. Examples include trusts, childrens assets, etc. The trusts have to be irrevocable for them to be outside of your estate. That means these trusts have their own tax id number and have their own tax rates. Unfortunately trust tax rates can be quite high. Thus theres a balance in terms of how much you move out and how much tax youre willing to pay for the privilege.

I think the people who are worried the most about overlap are those who believe in market efficiency and therefore like to have their investment spread out weighted by market capitalization. If everything is valued perfectly fairly, AKA if the market is perfectly efficient, then the best investment is going to be a total market index fund weighted by market capitalization. When people deviate this by overweighting certain funds, sectors, or stocks, basically what theyre doing is betting that they see a market inefficiency where others do not. Theyre betting that their decision will help them outperform the total market index fund basically. So if you have a specific reason to think that something is undervalued and you know something that other people dont, then thats the nature of stock picking. Most people suggest against it though, since they say statistically most people suck at it. A large part of investment is measuring potential risk, which can be difficult. Lets take as an example the total stock market index versus the SP 500 index. The total stock market index has an 80 overlap with the SP 500, because the SP 500 is the top 80 of the total market. That means that if you invested half in a total market and half in the SP 500, you would be overweighting the top 80 of the market. This actually slightly reduces the diversification of your investment, theoretically introducing uncompensated risk.

replies.text: Risk is defined as exposure to volatility The value of bonds are sufficiently uncorrelated to the performance of the stock market. Both of these assumptions, common in academic finance, fail to a meaningful extent in practical reality. Volatility is not risk. Risk is likelihood of permanent capital impairment, which prevents you from achieving your goals. Path dependency on the way to an outcome is irrelevant if you have no liquidity needs and your assets are not going to get wiped out to 0. Over a 2030 year period, who cares if I experience more volatility if Im compounding at 10? Id argue volatility is the price of achieving excess returns and should be welcomed, not viewed as some proxy of risk and thus minimized. As for the correlation point, this is both less true than often stated just observe crisis periods when correlations go to 1.0 and, for the needs of long term investors, not very relevant for the same path dependency reason cited above. A 100 bond portfolio for a young investor planning for eventual retirement is astonishingly risky, because they probably wont achieve their goal. Its not somehow low risk just the squiggly lines dont squiggle up and down as much as other assets do.

My only bonds are in my TDF through my 403b. They are actually surprisingly low yet which I appreciate just 10 of the fund for 2045 target date. I have my Roth as well and dont plan on including bonds yet. Im 43 and dont plan on including bonds at all for quite some time.

Its almost like someone complaining about the customers for a check cashing company while they own the check cashing company. Also I dont many treasuries. I prefer a mix of equities with my lower risk lower volatility segment simply being schd.
The actual answer is tied to something known as the Efficient Frontier. Mathematically, that is the sweet spot for riskadjusted returns and can include bonds at later ages

Yeah, of course those assumptions are arguable. Thats why theyre listed as assumptions. And of course it wont be attractive for some peoples investment approach. In actuality, different people define risk differently. I agree with most of what you say but think its misses the point of the concept slightly, if you dont like the use of the word risk here then replace it with volatility exposure and the points still stand. The information is still valuable in that it provides information on how volatility is not directly linked to expected return and that balancing a portfolio in different ways can allow for similar returns with less volatility exposure. This is a good thing to understand. The trade off of increasing expected return in exchange for volatility exposure is not always 11. The point is not to minimize exposure to volatility completely, or even to maximize return vs exposure to volatility. It is to find out how to minimize your exposure to volatility given a desired expected return, and the mechanisms with which people do that. Its an explanation of why people incorporate bonds in a portfolio, Im not telling people they should. Its also the advice echoed in The Intelligent Investor as well as Warren Buffet, and the subject of a lot of research. So its quite a bold claim to dismiss it as nonsense.

I think the whole Quantum Cryptography is a bit of a furphy to be honest. Classical cryptographic methods work well, and we have alternative classical methods for those that could be broken by a general purpose QC eg those based on Prime numbers. IMHO the interesting application is Quantum Annealing. Global solvers are useful in pretty much every industry you can think of. So Im tempted by firms like Dwave NASDAQQBTS. However, Dwaves current tech only solves a very specific subset of objective functions quadratic forms over binary variables, and further, theyve only got about 5000 qubits at this point, so they have not yet reached the scale where they can offer something that a Classical computer can not. So the price could go down quite a bit before going up, and if some other player has breakthrough, then it might never go up. I guess an ETF isnt a bad idea if you want exposure to the sector, because IMHO it is difficult at this stage to pick who will be the winners and the losers. If eg latest crop large language models started using an architecture that could be phrased as quadratic forms over binary variables, then Id be buying Dwave in a heartbeat, but as it stands, I still havent seen that killer application to warrant a purchase.
Quantum computing is still too nascent to be considered an emerging technology. You are better off focusing on other industries.

replies.text: Your comments dont really make sense. A circuit breaker is an exchange facility. And its not some random person that makes a decision to pause trading. Your point about afterhours makes no sense either. Its called afterhours because the exchanges are closed. What would circuit breakers have to do with that?

An official circuit breaker is whats stated in the definition above, which by nature is an externality of the market in real application. Upon reopening of trades shortly before close, positions have already then been made to execute, in favor of funds as many times retail is unable to set up trades to execute before closing again shortly after. This is an unnecessary interruption when market wide, only occurring when falling under SEC guidelines, in other cases, just as stock by stock circuit breakers are used to halt the trades of specific stocks, select exchanges halt trading, but not all exchanges creating a wildly unlevel market temporarily. I urge you to read the ENTIRE writup again, as Im restating whats been already written. You appear to possibly have missed some of the key inconsistencies of circuit breakers by exchanges when not falling under the official guidelines.

Your post wasnt particularly very interesting or compelling. And I dont necessarily agree with some of your conclusions. Do you have direct market microstructure experience by working with or at a broker or exchange, etc.? If not it would be more helpful if you cited some actual studies or data to validate your thesis. Tbh I only commented because I was wondering if you are a bot.

I believe you still dont understand the instances of exchanges halting trades unofficially when not under guidelines of an official breaker, therefore does not have available data to provide other than what is observable by price action in real time when the next one happens.
Working for a broker or exchange in your eyes is the only form of credibility regardless of market understanding ? If thats the case many economists if not the majority of them are not credible.
Ahh the NBER paper that the article mentions looks interesting. Thanks. Ill check that out.

Nah I was just making a point that I dont know what your background is and I dont generally believe random stuff that I read on social media. And most economist dont care about market microstructure. But if you can cite some helpful studies Im usually more interested in reading those. I can understand that there will be criticism about the use of circuit breakers. There will always be pros and cons.

I cant provide any advice on sector analysis but I have done some work on using economic data for recession nowcasting to estimate the probability of current recession state. Here are a handful of links I found helpful investingforaliving.us20170616mappingthetopeconomicindicatorsjune2017 I used Python and the FRED API to pull and analyze data, fit classification models and evaluate which data provided most accurate recession predictions. In the end I used individual logistic regression models on each economic data signal, then aggregated the individual model output into a ensemble logistic regression model for an overall prediction of current recession probability. Logistic regression models have a naturally probabilistic output signal and you can shrink the coefficients of the model to make it less certain to reduce impact of overfitting. One of the biggest hurdles in this kind of modeling is that data publication is significantly lagged and that initial data releases are often revised multiple times up to a year after initial publication. But you can access original release dates and original release data using ALFRED through the FRED API and run historical backtests with actual publication lag and data in the state of revision that would have been actually known at the time. Also, you have to be extra careful with how some data is recorded by FRED. For example, Q1 data is often recorded with a date of January 1 start of Q1 but is actually published weeks or months after the end of the first quarter AprJune. If you use the dates as is without adjusting for actually publication date you are essentially peaking into the future by 36 months. You can build a model that seems to work really, really well in backtest but in reality you would need a time machine for it to work in realtime. My model uses the following data series UNRATE, ICSA, CCSA, PAYEMS, USCONS, RRSFS, CSCICP03USM665S, IPDCONGD, INDPRO, GACDFSA066MSFRBPHI,AWHMAN, HTRUCKSSAAR,PERMIT, MSACSR, HOUST, T10Y3M, T10Y2Y, NFCI, ANFCI, NFCICREDIT, NFCIRISK, NFCINONFINLEVERAGE, SP500.

Technological risks from cybersecurity threats and the need for digital investments. ESG risks impacting brand reputation and consumer perception. Conclusion Given the mixed financial performance, market sentiments, and diverse risks facing V.F. Corp, it is recommended to hold the stock for now. I was a scientist in the nuclear industry in the 80s and 90s, its going to be a decade before I retire. Ive worked on reactors, reprocessing and warhead production. In the UK. Large reactors can use natural unenriched uranium and are easier to defuel, for Pu239 production. Now. The UK, US and France have too much weapons grade plutonium if anything, so large, difficult to decommission reactors are unnecessary. Theyre massive capital projects SMRs require enriched uranium, but theyre just built in a factory, moved to site, then theyre defuelled and buried when were done with them. Theyre very similar to the submarine reactors that Rolls Royce and Westinghouse Brookfield corp have been making for 60 years. There are also a bunch of startups with high hopes but no engineering experience. My bet is on Rolls Royce. Its a car company that diversified into jet engines and reactors unlike Tesla, which is a car company trying to diversify into novelties and toys. Im also invested in USbased Brookfield because its a great company like an infrastructurefocussed Berkshire Hathaway. Both have been doing very well recently for their shareholders. Small enriched uranium SMRs cant be used to make atom bombs, so they can be made on a production line and sold anywhere without nuclear proliferation concerns. But the 530 enriched fuel has to be purchased from the US, UK, France, China or Russia the nuclear gulf states. Uranium isnt the critical bottleneck you all think it is. The value is added by gas centrifuging UF6. Only governments can do that.

The DD is indeed bending reality. In addition to Vogtle 34, there was another project that survived the postFukushima wipeout of US new nuclear builds. That was V C Summer 23, another pair of AP1000s. Westinghouse was so far behind schedule and over budget in building these four plants that it went bankrupt. Thats why a private equity firm like Brookfield owns them in the first place before it sold half to Comeco. The V C Summer utility decided not to continue, but the Vogtle utility did, at great cost. Its because of this experience and the fact that wind and especially solar are far cheaper these days that no one is looking to build more AP1000s, or any other large nuclear reactors, in the US. Europe has had similar experiences in France, Finland, and the UK. Among nonauthoritarian countries in the last couple of decades, only South Korea has managed to build large nuclear reactors on a reasonable budget and schedule. Id be very wary of all the hype around nuclear, be it uranium, SMRs, or large reactors.

Oh, the AP1000 is a great design, as youll see downthread on the other reply to my comment. Definitely the best LWR design currently on the market. But the nuclear industry always claims that theyll learn their lessons and the next build will be smoother and on time and budget. And it never is. Basically every plant built in the 70s and 80s in the US had huge overruns, and many were cancelled after TMI. Even Watts Bar took much longer to complete than expected. Flamanville in France and Olkiluoto in Finland were similar. Frances original build out in the 70s was similarly over. Taiwan ended up cancelling the ABWRs in Longmen, and that was after a dozen or so were built in Japan. Unless youre an authoritarian country, or maybe South Korea, youre very likely to take far more money and time to build every large nuclear reactor. This time wont be different. This is unfortunately why the nuclear industry, which should be a perfect complement to solar and wind, and perfect for AI, is instead a sunset industry.

Intrinsic Value Silver, like gold, has been used as a store of value for centuries. Its a tangible asset, meaning it has physical presence and cannot be easily devalued like fiat currencies. People trust precious metals during times of financial instability because they retain value over time. Hedge Against Inflation Historically, silver has acted as a hedge against inflation. When the value of paper currency decreases due to inflation, the price of silver typically rises. This is because silver, like gold, tends to hold its value as fiat currencies lose purchasing power. Industrial and SafeHaven Demand Unlike gold, silver has significant industrial demand. Its used in electronics, solar panels, medical devices, and other applications. This dual demand as an industrial and investment metal creates a unique dynamic where silver benefits both from market speculation and physical demand, making it more resilient. Historical Precedent During past economic crises, such as the 2008 financial crisis, silver and gold prices surged as investors sought out these assets to protect their wealth from collapsing stock markets and devaluing currencies. I love SiC and WOLF, but I think the target within the next 612 months is a little high. Instead, I think 2030 is more reasonable. They basically doubled in the last week due to chips funding, but they need to execute. Execution primarily involves filling more orders and reducing CapEx, which they seem set up fairly well to do based on recent transcripts Ive readlistened to. They will have slightly higher manufacturing capabilities at the Mohawk Valley fab than they initially predicted. Overall, I like WOLF because they are the most experienced when it comes to making wafers of size. They are currently transitioning their wafer production from 150 to 200 mm, which is a great sign. On a more qualitative note, when I watch their YouTube podcasts, I feel that they get into the depths of the technology which I appreciate because to me, it shows that the scientists and engineers are leading the company. Other companies will for sure offer SiC in the future, but will they have the highest market share, Im not sure. WOLF is primarily focused on making the wafers, while sum companies focus on wafer production and device development. Only time will tell of course, my recommendation is to look into the tech and prepare for a moderately bumpy ride. After two years I project itll double and be around 3035.

Guys, if you are new to this sector, please read this message as a bit of advice from someone who has been in this investment since 2019. It is a volatile sector. Expect big drops of 20 in mid cap stocks and even more in small caps. Within a week. This happens also for the upside like we see this month for a lot of the U equities. That said, there is unbelievable valuation and immense upside to many uranium juniors and business focused on the fuel cycle enrichment etc. This sector moves at a glacial speed, and many stocks do get ahead of themselves. Do lots of homework on companies that are developers of mines. The only producers that need to be considered for a newbie is Cameco, Uranium energy Corp, boss energy and energy fuels. If you want more then look at Sprotts Uranium information on their website. Dont listen to hype on YouTube, X, and other sources. Its a great opportunity to buy a non fungible, scarce and undervalued commodity, but dont expect to make life changing money if you consider yourself an average investor, much of the easy money has been made already in the sitting and waiting. Now is the time to look for value, performance and the companies that are actually going to be able to mine this resources at significant quantities well into the future. Alongside the companies involved in the other services in the sector. This bull market is not a flash in the pan. This time for the nuclear industry, its game on.

The uranium market is already seeing a mix of tight supply and rising demand for nuclear energy, especially as countries push for clean energy solutions. Kazakhstans recent production cuts and the U.S. banning Russianenriched uranium are only going to add more pressure to an already constrained market. On top of that, demand for uranium is expected to grow as China and other nations continue to build nuclear reactors. Prices have been fluctuating, but many experts believe they will rise again due to these supply and demand dynamics. Whats also interesting is how big tech companies are now getting involved. Microsoft recently signed a deal to revive the Three Mile Island nuclear plant to power its data centers, while Oracle is building small modular reactors SMRs to fuel its AI data centers. These reactors are expected to deliver over 1 gigawatt of electricity, showing just how critical energy demand has become in powering AI growth. This could lead to even higher demand.

To add to this, you can also add the credit spread trades that are available between the countries who export uranium and who want uranium. This website Gives a good oversight of importance and exporters country and stock. Look at OECD for import of uranium and if you compare the spread of the yield curve between the two you scrape free money as the thesis is correct. There is a uranium shift going on.

Still waiting for liquid fluoride thorium reactor LFTR to come online. These can convert Thorium232 into Thorium233. This decays into Protactinium233, which further decays into Uranium233. Protactinium233 can be removed from the liquid salt of a tworegion MSR by reductive extraction into liquid bismuth. Basically a breeder reactor that uses a cheaper and more abundant fuel source. This style of reactor was designed in the 1950s and I honestly believe the main reason this hasnt been developed further is more due to proliferation risks than cost or feasibility. Since the Protactinium233 can be extracted rather easily and would be of high concentration, it would reduce a lot of the work needed to make a nuclear weapon. Mainly removal of neutron emitters and other purification steps to get to 95 purity of Uranium233. Uranium233 is a fissile isotope.

TL,DR from ChatGPT Summary Uranium Market Report Price Trends Since 2020, uranium prices have surged from 21lb to 106lb in February 2024, currently stabilizing at 83lb. The report suggests that this increase is only the beginning, with further growth expected. Uranium Overview Uranium is a naturally occurring radioactive metal, primarily used for nuclear energy. The key isotopes are U238 used in military applications and U235 used to fuel nuclear reactors. U235 is particularly efficient, with one kilogram producing energy equivalent to over 3 million pounds of coal. HALEU and Enrichment Highassay lowenriched uranium HALEU is critical for advanced nuclear reactors. The U.S. is investing in domestic HALEU production to reduce reliance on imports, especially from Russia, which controls a significant portion of global enrichment capacity. The U.S. has started producing HALEU domestically, supported by government initiatives. Supply Challenges Uranium supply is tightening due to depleted inventories and underinvestment in mining. Mines are expensive and slow to develop, often taking 1015 years to become operational. The market is shifting to rely more on primary mining as secondary supplies dwindle. Primary production is forecasted to decrease by 30 by 2035, highlighting a potential supply gap. Demand Growth The U.S., China, and France account for 58 of global uranium demand. As of 2024, there are 440 operating reactors worldwide, with many more planned. The World Nuclear Association predicts a 28 increase in demand from 20232030 and a 51 rise from 20312040, driven by global clean energy goals. Global Production Kazakhstan is the leading producer, supplying 43 of global uranium. However, production cuts due to delays and shortages could put further pressure on prices. The U.S. has also increased its domestic uranium production in 2024, signaling a shift toward selfreliance. Investment Insights The report suggests that mining companies are wellpositioned to benefit from rising uranium prices. Companies like Cameco, NexGen Energy, and ETFs such as URNM and NUKZ are highlighted as investment opportunities. Big tech companies like Amazon and Google are also investing in nuclear energy, emphasizing the growing interest in this sector. Conclusion The report anticipates a bullish market for uranium due to increasing demand and limited supply. With countries seeking clean energy and reducing carbon emissions, uraniums role as a key energy source is set to grow, potentially driving prices to unprecedented levels. Investment Disclaimer The recommendations are not financial advice.

no because unlike with other forms of fuel, uranium costs are a tiny portion of the overall cost of building and operating a reactor. the majority of the cost is the upfront capex for building the reactor 10s of billions for big multireactor plants. then, the marginal cost of loading them with reactor is almost negligible in comparison. due to how expensive reactors are to build, countries cant afford to let then sit idle regardless of uranium prices. It was calculated that 700lbs is the cutoff at which point it becomes uneconomical to keep running the reactors. this is 8x the current price. due to these factors, uranium supply is priceinelastic

Not badly. That price for uranium is in the multiple hundred dollar range 500 to 800 compared to current 84lb. Unlike gas and oil, the U3O8 fuel is not a major part of the overall cost to a utility running a nuclear plant. Its something like 20 of the cost. When CapEx is in the billions, you dont just not buy fuel to keep it running.

Global turnover in U is pretty large but a rather small share of it ever meaningfully sees the market. The industry is vertically integrated to an incredibly high degree. A given mine might be in Canada, but it is owned by a consortium of utilities that ultimately use the metal and the price is just an exercise in accounting, the actual cost to the utilities being their share of the wages and operation costs of the mine, because while they might Buy the U, that amounts to taking money out of their left pocket and putting it into the right one. This means that mines opening up or closing that do sell on the open U market can swing the price like mad. It doesnt matter to most of the industry.

Be cautious, bigger dogs than you have thought this was SaaS and would taste like chicken and came away without much to show for it other than a 3.5B write off. The space is pretty toxic right now, it turns out keeping 10,000 courses up to date takes more effort than expected and if you stop paying authors well, they stop making courses well. These two companies have very different approaches, and one might appeal to you, but dont mistake these for software companies.

Counter argument Elearning is screwed. If you have any question about any topic, you can just ask chatgpt. Rigid courses are things of the past and the cost of knowledge will be nearly free to anyone who wants to learn.

These arent really SaaS businesses in the traditional sense. Normally, software companies ingrain themselves in their users and enjoy yearsdecades of recurring revenue. eLearning companies are built on the idea of being a temporary subscription, similar to dating apps. Bumble trades at a 0.8 PS and Match is at 3.2 for comparison.

funny, did a dcf on cour last week because as used it for some astronomy courses. wont go in depth but it was valued around 2.41 billion but was based on perpetuity growth mode and 5 growth rate on 5 year cash flows and 1.5 on terminal growth.
Personally Id classify both as SaaS...I didnt know about the pluralsight situation tho...gonna have to look into that

I think leveraging AI for different use cases might actually be a boon for Elearning...using AI for coding, content marketing, design, really anything at all, is itself a discipline that needs specific skills

I would classify both as SaaS. They are just B2C SaaS like duolingo, match group, netflix, bumble. But still subscription revenue model for access to software. Just not B2B, and churn is not great as a result. But yea I see your point on retention profile...though I do believe there are enterpriseinstitutional customers that use the platform for workforce or bulk trainings. Their churn profile is different probably

True, I think it just becomes a lot harder to determine the future growth rate or an appropriate discount rate for an industry with such a high turnoverlow retention. Its not like Spotify or Netflix where the goal is to retain customers forever indefinitely. So the multiples investors are willing to pay will likely be lower.

Im bullish because 1. Im anticipating consumer income and wealth will increase in 2025. This is broadly good for B2C apps 2. AI job and skill disruption will cause an increase in individuals seeking to upskill or change roles 3. I dont think Coursera and Udemy have fully tapped international markets to their full potential. Like India or Brazil. Could be a source of growth. 4. For a growing public saas, 1.5x2x is just very cheap. No such thing as a bad stock, just a bad price!

Good analysis. The little I know about development of systems following Functional Safety ISO26262 tells me that Tesla vision only AI design will never be able to proof level 5 autonomy. It is escalable true, but never safe enough to be approved on the roads.

Some minor details in need of correctionclarification. Radar and lidar are also capable of detecting and classifying pedestrians either by themselves or as part of a multimodal sensor suite. In fact they can be better than cameras in some circumstances, low light as you mentioned. Some lidars also give Dopplerrelative speed not sure if Waymos does but I know AURs does. Video processing is necessarily a much more resource intensive task than processing lidar or radar data. Now everyone I know that has radar and lidar also has cameras, so that may not be important but there are probably some optimizations that having multiple sensors allows a reduction in the amount of video that needs to be processed. Rapid iteration is not a differentiator, everyone doing self driving Waymo included can push updates whenever they want. Most also use Continuous integration pipelines. Regulatory hurdles are mostly propagandafake news auto companies self certify for safety, other than FMVSS rules which are testable requirements NHTSA can verify. FMVSS rules are very easy to comply with and say nothing about autonomy. There are some FMVSS changes required to remove steering wheel pedals and other things but those changes have been in process for years and should be done soon if it hasnt already happened, not familiar with the latest status. The easy work around is to simply not delete these until the rules change, theres also a waiver process that some companies I believe have successfully completed to delete these components. The real regulatory hurdle is liability, and needing to pay out millions in damages when a court determines your product killed someone and the manufacturer is liable. In other words the only real barrier is tech readiness. Regulatory hurdles are just an excuse that wallstreet types tend to buy.

Ok, Ill play the devils advocate. And I hate doing this Just assume, that China built up a giant real estate bubble. That bubble went close to bust, so China did, what any reasonable regulator would have done and created a giant credit bubble, which it injected into the real estate bubble, in order to stabilize that one. People got loans, which, even if they didnt miss their payments, they wouldnt be able to pay off in their lifetime and their heirs would have to take over. Then Beijing did an actually reasonable thing It tried to let the air slowly out of that bubble. This led to some collapses. Nothing to serious for the system. But the economy slowed down. And cashflows dried up. And money started fleeing the country in trillions. The main reason for this was not the government action, but the Corona lockdown and ripple effects. Those, who still invested in the country chose a secure investment 10 year chinese treasury bonds. They bought so many of them, that the state begun discouraging it, because banks going to long led to the collapse of the SVB and they saw that threat if there was a run on chinese banks. But the economy slowed further and the real aconomic data they saw became troubling. So the state did, what any good state would have done They set up a big stimulus package. And everything was great. Except it wasnt. Because now there was a stock market rally and everyone everywhere who did not want to miss the boat suddenly needed liquidity to buy stocks. And the approximately 4.000 small to mid cap chinese banks who are to long in their investments get in trouble providing that liquidity. So they do, what every good bank does Instead of rolling over the loans they give to local government, they want repayment. But there is an issue. While the central state of China has massive reserves, the local governments are 34 trillion Dollar in debt. And they cant pay. So the central government declares to loan a couple of dozen billion Dollar to local governments. And everybody thinks, thats just another stimulus. And they cheer. And they draw more liquidity from the banks with the 10 year treasuries. To invest in the stock market. Which is financed by the banks. Which hold the bad mortgages. And whose liquidity is locked up. Im not saying China is going to crash. I atill dontwant to believe it. I hold some ETFs myself. But everything I wrote is more or less the case according to various different pieces of financial reporting. So in order to fix this, China will have to do a lot more that what has beend announced so far. I suppose they will. They might be less dogmatic about letting the market regulate itself, than the US was back in the day. But there is an element of risk involved in China investments. And everything related to that.

The U.S. Federal Aviation Administration FAA is preparing to release a crucial regulation that will help pave the way for the commercialization of eVTOL aircraft in the U.S., according to Christopher Coes, acting under secretary of transportation for policy at the U.S. Department of Transportation. Speaking at Honeywells Advanced Air Mobility AAM Summit on Sept. 19, Coes announced that the final special federal aviation regulation SFAR for poweredlift pilot certification and operations is expected to be published in the next month.

Update 2 This information is huge regarding final SFAR FAA Rule The U.S. Federal Aviation Administration FAA is preparing to release a crucial regulation that will help pave the way for the commercialization of eVTOL aircraft in the U.S., according to Christopher Coes, acting under secretary of transportation for policy at the U.S. Department of Transportation. Speaking at Honeywells Advanced Air Mobility AAM Summit on Sept. 19, Coes announced that the final special federal aviation regulation SFAR for poweredlift pilot certification and operations is expected to be published in the next month. I think youll see it is quite responsive to industry comments, Coes told attendees. It will come well ahead of certifications that the FAA is working very hard with our manufacturers. The SFAR was a hot topic at last years summit, where the draft version faced considerable criticism. Industry concerns focused on the certification process for pilots, the requirement for dual flight controls, energy reserves for electric aircraft, and flight simulation training devices. Many in the industry felt the rules governing pilot certification and operations of a novel technology like poweredlift eVTOLs should be modernized to reflect the unique aspects of electrification and range. However, at this years summit, the mood had shifted toward cautious optimism for the release of the final SFAR. Theres great anticipation for the rule, which were told is coming in just a few weeks, said Kristie Greco Johnson, senior vice president of government affairs with the National Business Aviation Association NBAA. If the FAA can deliver the rule in just a few short weeks, itll be a major accomplishment for the agency. While Coes contends the final SFAR will be released in the next month, the FAA technically has until Dec. 16 to finalize the regulation, according to the FAA reauthorizaton bill. The same bill also mandated that a notice of proposed rulemaking NPRM for unmanned aerial systems UAS operating beyond visual line of sight BVLOS be issued by Sept. 16. However, the FAA missed that deadline, raising concerns about the SFARs timely release. There is broad consensus that the U.S. faces stiff competition from global players to lead in AAM. With first movers like Joby Aviation and Archer Aviation aiming for a 2025 commercialization of eVTOLs, the pressure is on the FAA to meet expectations.

How the hell does their eVTOL have have fewer failure points? They have more motors and more propellers not to mention the hinges that have to move to allow them to transition from vertical to horizontal flight. These thing arent exactly maintenance free, they still have to be inspected, lubed and maintained not to mention that there are more of them which means more places for thing to break or go wrong. Also how does an eVTOL pilot cost less? They still have to be trained to the standard that the FAA requires and since they are flying a vehicle that can fly like a helicopter or an airplane, they need to have training in both, something that is certainly not cheap. Being quieter might be nice but it offers not much of a benefit. Any aircraft that is within the noise limits will work, you dont get bonus points for being quieter. And using nontraditional fuels isnt really a flex when most airports dont have the chargers for them. Also being cool doesnt mean useful. Sharks with laser eyes are cool, but not really of much benefit. Overall I see a more complex aircraft with an abysmal range, exotic requirements and not much of an opportunity for cost savings.

As of September 2024, the West continues to impose heavy sanctions and restrictions on imports of many Russian goods, particularly in the wake of the ongoing conflict in Ukraine. However, some Western countries still import specific Russian products, though in significantly reduced volumes compared to pre2022 levels. Key imports that continue to flow from Russia to Europe and the U.S. include 1. Energy Products Although many European countries have drastically cut their dependence on Russian natural gas and oil, certain imports like liquefied natural gas LNG still persist, albeit at reduced levels. 2. Metals Russian aluminum and derivative products are still imported, though the U.S. imposes a 200 tariff on aluminum and derivative products smelted or cast in Russia, and similar measures are applied to steel and other metals. 3. NonEnergy Commodities Certain agricultural products like fertilizers continue to be imported into Europe due to their critical role in food production. Overall, the proportion of Russian goods imported by the West has significantly decreased due to sanctions, tariffs, and a broader pivot away from reliance on Russian supply chains. The most prominent exceptions are energy and select raw materials, often subject to very high tariffs or specific exclusions. Admiteddly, severed all ties is a bit excessive, severed most of them is more accurate.

Fair question. No. Peter Beck and RocketLab were wandering around for some time. Building sounding rockets. Building InstantEyes basically a rocket launched camera, before small drones were common. Building a Viscous Liquid Monopropellant version of the AIM9 Sidewinder missile They were one 6 employees back then. Developing their own heat shield material Lockheed later on bought that heat shield material. Beck simply didnt have the money to start with a real rocket program right away. He first had to prove himself to his seed founders some NZ internet millionaire. Later on prove himself to DARPA. Later on prove himself to other military agencies. And then convince some venture capital firms to hand him several million dollars to develop a real launch vehicle. And they operated for 18 years. But they did burn through much cash. Especially during the first years. Total funding till their first Electron launch was like 150 million.

Seriously, these space stocks LUNR, RKLB and ASTS are for playing short term IMO. Long term wise, the closed price today is even lower than it was in 0621. Its a bad investment, period. I made some money with LUNR but never considered to long the stock.

That will be an interesting time. Current Starship estimates are 100 to 150 tons to LEO. So 6.6 to 10 times more than Neutrons barge landing LEO capacity. I am not sure about the price though. SpaceX already spend 5 billion dollars on the starship development. And the first few years the starships are already sold Artemis mission, Musks Mars mission etc. Another important aspect if you deploy a constellation like Starlink you do not put every satellite into the same orbital plane. You need to insert the satellites into different orbital planes so launching 100 or even 150 tons of satellites into a single orbital plane does not make sense. You could of course solve that with orbital transfer vehicles, but that adds weight and cost. So lets see how that plays out long term. If Starships becomes dominating RocketLab positioned Neutron well to scale it up. Instead of Merlins gas generator engine they went with a ox rich staged combustion engine. One can expect performance gains over time look at how much Blue Origin gets out of a ox rich staged combustion engine of similar size. If satellites and payloads in general become significantly larger and heavier due to Starship RocketLab could use the same engines for the heavy lift rocket and maybe even use the Neutron 1st stage as a 2nd stage of the heavy lift rocket. Starship is 50 meters high and 9 meter wide. Neutron is 42 meters high and 7 meters wide. Plus the tank parts are potentially stretchable.

Market is launch constrained . Regardless of how cheap starship can be for per ton, people will pay whatever they have to pay to launch something reliably. So doesnt matter if spacex is so cheap, if there rocket is full and has a backlog months out...your gonna cough up all the money you got to get on the second cheapest option neutron. It also wont surprise me you see a neutron heavy or something else and expand in scale 57 years down the road okay. And rocketlab works with a superior material. So if they make a rocket the same size as spacex, itll be a better rocket because one works with a 20th century material and the other works with a 21st century material.

And hopefully with neutron flying they will swing to profitability. I admit all these space stocks are risky and an obvious gamble. Personally I believe in RKLB and also ASTS.
